dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA sits at a pew in a largely empty church - there two other WORSHIPPERS dotted about; there is no service. is looking at a statue of Madonna and Child. A PRIEST passes PHILOMENA and stops to talk. He is dresse a black sweater and dog collar rather than formal robes.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Hello Philomena, haven’t seen you for a while?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I just came in to light a candle.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Someone special?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Yes. But she pointedly doesn’t elaborate any further. The PRIE tries to continue the conversation:

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: How’s the new hip?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: It's very good. It’s Ti-tanium.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Oh, the bionic woman... She smiles, but he can see she’s not really in the mood f talking. PRIEST (CONT’D) Well, always nice to see you. He carries on. PHILOMENA returns her gaze to the Madonna Child.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she leaves the church, PHILOMENA dips her fingers Holy Water and blesses herself.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. JANE’S HOUSE - NIGHT PHILOMENA is walking along a street at night, traffic swishing past her, lost in thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER ANUNCIATA
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to do it!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: BLACK.
dialogues.text: Under the black screen we start to FADE UP a voice:

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+» blood glucose fine. Liver function, kidney function, normal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN SIXSMITH, mid-40s, sits listening to someone (as y unseen), as a series of test results are read out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platelet count normal, haemoglobin levels normal, blood pressure, 131 over 92...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Pouncing on this) Isn't that high? Now we see ROBERT, Martin’s doctor, mid-50s, chipper. Caption: London, 2002 ROBERT looks up from a folder of results he’s reading and familiar with Martin’s hypochondria, ignores the question

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Weight fine... could do with losing a centimetre or two off your waist. Stool sample outstanding... MARTIN finally perks up at this, raises his eyebrow, plea with himself. ROBERT notices this... ROBERT (cont’d) No, that means you haven't provided one yet.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh right, yes. No, I’d remember.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (As he shuts the file) Did you think it didn’t stink or something? (Little smile from MARTIN) There’s basically nothing wrong with you Martin. Um... do you run?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well... I walk a lot.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Try running.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Worried) Do I need to?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I do it. Good for your body and... good for your head - Kate says you think you’re mildly depressed? MARTIN shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I got fired. I’m unemployed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it wasn’t your fault, was it?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That’s probably why I’m depressed -— I was sacked for saying something I didn't say! Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Try running-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I said the exact opposite of what I was sacked for! Another silence. ROBERT tries a different tack:

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What are you working on at the moment?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Beat) I was... thinking of writing a book.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That’s good. What about?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Russian history.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (Beat) What makes you think it’s depression and not just feeling sorry for yourself? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Doesn’t have to be Russian history - could be something else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen year old PHILOMENA LEE, pretty, dark haired, wea lovely summer dress, that same crucifix glinting in the sunshine. She picks her way wide-eyed, through the crowd; bright lights, the air filled with noise and excitement.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: You looking for something? YOUNG PHILOMENA turns to see JOHN, early 20s, with a gro his FRIENDS by a beer tent, smiling at her.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No. She walks off, he follows.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I haven’t seen yous any place. Where are you from? JOHN follows her past the brightly coloured stalls, still cradling his glass of beer. JOHN (cont'd) Are you from Limerick then? YOUNG PHILOMENA stops by a hoop-la, excited by the attent but trying to play it - at least a little - cool. JOHN (cont'd) Here have a drink of my beer. He holds out his beer. She shakes her head. JOHN (cont'd) Go on take it - what’s the matter with you. She relents, takes the glass from him and takes a swig. S doesn’t like the taste. JOHN (cont'd) I like your dress. Did you make it yourself?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Indignant ) No I bought it in a shop. Anyway, me auntie told me I’m not to talk to strange men like you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sure I’m not strange. Look at yer man over there... He nods to a ruddy-faced man, early 20s, (DECLAN), his an swinger trousers tied up with string, buying a toffee app from a stall and looking at his purchase with reverence. JOHN (cont'd) Has a rope for a belt. He should put some jam on his shoes and invite his trousers down for tea. YOUNG PHILOMENA giggles.  JOHN (cont'd) That’s who your auntie was talking about.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t mind a bite of his toffee apple.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You want a toffee apple? (Calls out) Declan! DECLAN looks over, smiles, revealing one and a half teeth JOHN (cont'd) Come over here. DECLAN, a simple soul, dutifully troops over. JOHN (cont'd) Do you want this beer? There’s about half a pint left. DECLAN nods enthusiastica JOHN nods to the toffee apple, a single bite out of it. JOHN (cont'd) I‘1l swap you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN and YOUNG PHILOMENA kiss passionately in a gap betwe two stalls, hidden from view. JOHN brushes his hand down side of her breast to her waist, then slips down to her bottom. The shot CONTINUES to her hand; OOV she moans softly... she drops the toffee apple she’s holding.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. FRONT ROOM, JANE’S HOUSE - DUSK CLOSE on PHILOMENA LEE, an elderly Irish lady, watching T the blue light playing on the lenses of her glasses. Thou distracted, distant with her thoughts, she is half paying attention to a news report on TV about the purchase, for forty nine and a half million pounds, of a painting of by Rubens - ‘The Slaughter of The Innocents’. Her daughter JANE, dark-haired, late 30s, enters in a hur She pulls a coat over an outfit of black skirt and white (like a receptionist in Soho House might wear).

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Right, just go up and turn their lights out in half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn’t she know you’ve got a proper job?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m just helping her out tonight - she’s short staffed. The painting flashes up on TV, depicting bloody biblical carnage.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Distracted, talking to the TV not JANE) Fancy spending all that money on a God awful thing like that? If it was me I’d take everyone to the Brent Cross shopping centre and I’d say you can have one thing, whatever you like - two things. JANE drops her keys in her bag, she’s ready to go:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: So I'll be back before midnight. Okay? PHILOMENA doesn’t respond. JANE (cont'd) Mum? JANE sees her mother is looking down at something in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: And I'd get myself a brand new Nissan Micro automatic...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Mother? She sees PHILOMENA is clutching a small, old, black and w photo with serrated edges. She is late for work but begin sense something is badly wrong. JANE (cont'd) What is it mum? What’s the matter? PHILOMENA looks up at JANE, tears in her eyes. JANE nods the photo. JANE (cont'd) What's that? PHILOMENA’S hands start to shake as, slowly, she holds it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Voice barely a whisper) It’s his birthday. He would have been fifty today...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Beat) Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA, her sweaty face contorted as she screams in agony. She lays back on a bed, legs in stirrups, in an improvised delivery room above the chapel. She’s in the advanced stages of labour - but there are complications. As two OLDER NUNS look on impotently, wringing their hand she is attended by a younger nun just a few years older t her. This is Sister ANUNCIATA, pale, red-haired, terrifie She looks at a pair of forceps in a metal bowl and knows should attempt to use them - but they seem monstrous, medieval. YOUNG PHILOMENA grabs ANUNCIATA’S hand as anoth spasm grips her body.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Don’t let them put him in the ground. It’s cold there... it’s dark there... ANUNCIATA extricates her hand and hurries away from the b leaving YOUNG PHILOMENA frightened, distraught...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other inmates of Roscrea, ‘fallen’ YOUNG GIRLS like Philomena, a couple of them obviously pregnant, kneel by their beds in prayer. They are watched over by MOTHER BARBARA, mid-50s, kind-faced, the most senior nun at Rosc From upstairs they can hear PHILOMENA crying out in pain; see how frightened the YOUNG GIRLS are, some in tears.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER BARBARA
dialogues.text: (Soothing voice) Pray girls. Pray for the Magdalen. As they whisper their prayers ANUNCIATA enters the dormit and hurries up to MOTHER BARBARA.

dialogues.speaker: ANUNCIATA
dialogues.text: Reverend Mother, please - we must get a doctor. The baby is the wrong way round, it’s breech.  10. MOTHER BARBARA is aware the YOUNG GIRLS are listening intently. In that same, soothing voice, she replies:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER BARBARA
dialogues.text: It’s in God’s hands now. Now we see the hardness in her, the darkness of her eyes. MOTHER BARBARA (cont'd) The pain is her penance. It will help absolve her of her sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA thrashes about, delirious. The OLDER NUNS do no more than press wet cloths to her head. ANUNCIATA enters, looks at YOUNG PHILOMENA in such pain. sees again the forceps on the side and cries out in angui

dialogues.speaker: ANUNCIATA
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to do it! Mother Barbara’s words are in her head... ‘it’s in God’s hands now’... but she cannot do it - she cannot just stan and let the girl die. She picks up the forceps and plunge between YOUNG PHILOMENA’S legs. On the girl’s scream..

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MOTHER BARBARA'S STUDY, ROSCREA -— DAY Jump back to two months earlier. YOUNG PHILOMENA stands before MOTHER BARBARA and YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE, Mother Barbara’s number two, thin-faced, early 40s. Ashamed of h swollen, pregnant belly, she can barely meet their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: Did you let him put his hands on you?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Beat, humiliated) Yes sister.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER BARBARA
dialogues.text: And did you enjoy that? Did you enjoy your sin? YOUNG PHILOMENA doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: Did you take your knickers down? YOUNG PHILOMENA looks at the two older women, their eyes boring into her. She is too petrified to answer.  11.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER BARBARA
dialogues.text: Answer Sister Hildegarde - did you take them down?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Tears in her eyes) Yes. YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE settles back into her chair, turn sniffily to Mother BARBARA:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: He got an awful lot for his toffee apple.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh Reverend Mother the sisters at school never told us anything about babies or... the thing.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER BARBARA
dialogues.text: Did your mother not tell you?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: Her mother died ten years ago.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER BARBARA
dialogues.text: Oh, God rest her soul... (Sudden venom) But don’t dare to blame the sisters! You are the cause of this shame. You and your indecency!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the birth. With the forceps and her strong finger ANUNCIATA pushes and twists the tiny body inside YOUNG PHILOMENA, lying back, drenched in sweat, moaning in pain Finally, with a gush of pale red liquid onto the white sh ANUNCIATA pulls out the baby’s head, dragging a new life God's world. It’s over and ANUNCIATA, overcome with emoti holds up the newborn baby to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: ANUNCIATA
dialogues.text: It’s a boy. She hands him to YOUNG PHILOMENA, who takes him to her ch

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I knew. Caption: Roscrea, 1952 The door to the delivery room opens. MOTHER BARBARA stand the doorway, taking in the sight of YOUNG PHILOMENA cradl her baby. She makes the sign of the cross.  12.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER BARBARA
dialogues.text: Thank the Lord. Aware of MOTHER BARBARA’S icy glare but bitter at her hypocrisy, ANUNCIATA is forced to also make the sign.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. MARION’S HOUSE - NIGHT To establish a white stucco-fronted Georgian town house, bathed in the golden sun of late evening. SFX sounds of a party from inside.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARION’S HOUSE - NIGHT A drinks party at a central London town house, an informa gathering for journalists and New Labour types. WAITRESSE serving drinks to GUESTS. JANE, worried, is serving canapes (or maybe she is going round with bottles of wine topping up glasses). And now w REVEAL behind her MARTIN, looking ill at ease, wishing he wasn’t there. DAVID, an old friend, same age, chatting wi KEITH, 50s, and a woman, 40s, a no-nonsense look about he (SALLY MITCHELL).

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Martin! MARTIN forces a smile and joins them. DAVID (cont'd) (Gestures to KEITH) Keith you know. (Then to SALLY) Sally Mitchell this is Martin Sixsmith, used to be the BBC’s man in Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And Washington.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And then became a spin doctor for the government, until it all went a bit tits up. Is that a fair summation Martin? DAVID is not drunk but has obviously had a few drinks. JANE, serving, is all ears.  13.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Pretty much. I suppose if you shovel shit for long enough, you'll end up with some on your shoes. They laugh politely.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeh but you got it on your head - how did you manage that? They laugh louder - MARTIN too.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, well, you’ve got to have a sense of humour about these things.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What are you up to at the moment?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m thinking of writing a book. On Russian history. .? They look at him and no-one responds. Horrible eggy momen MARTIN (cont'd) Or something else. Might try going back to journalism-

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I remember you! You’re the one who sent that terrible e-mail saying-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No I didn’t. Common mistake.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (Line overlaps with his) -it was a good day to bury bad news on 9/11... I thought that was you?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, that was someone else. What I actually did was, one year later, on the day of Princess Margaret's funeral, send an e-mail saying let’s make sure the only thing we ‘bury’ today - inverted commas - is Princess Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Which is slightly different.  14.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s totally different. But the papers said it was another e-mail about burying bad news, nobody from the government defended me and... I got royally fucked up the arse by a bunch of self interested spineless shits.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (Sarcastic) But you’ve still got a sense of humour about it?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Defiantly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well if you want to get back into journalism, talk to Sally.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh I just do, you know, sob stories, human interest stuff - not really your cup of tea is it. MARTIN looks at her awkwardly. It isn’t, but he doesn’t w to say it isn’t. SALLY (cont'd) But I’1l be happy to have a look if you want to push any ideas my way?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes... please. To escape his embarrassment he walks over to JANE, standi close by. MARTIN (cont'd) Could I get a glass of... Pinot Grigio please? JANE is obviously not in the mood for niceties:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It’s just red or white.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh yes, sorry. White then please. But as she pours it, there is the first glimmer of recognition. She’s sure she’s seen Martin before.  15.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I hope you don’t mind me asking but didn't you used to be a reporter on News At Ten?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Erm, I was the BBC’S correspondent yes, in Moscow and then Washington.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I know a woman, you see, and she had a baby when she was a teenager and she kept it a secret for fifty years - we only found out about it today. And the baby was taken from her by these nuns and they made her have it adopted. And she kept it a secret all this time... (Beat) It’s my mother.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes I guessed.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Would that be of any interest you to you - that kind of thing?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well, I’m actually quite busy writing a book at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Russian history... (On her glazed reaction) -which is actually fascinating. And what you’re talking about is a human interest story, which I don’t really do.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Why not? He sees, at the other end of the kitchen, SALLY MITCHELL, DAVID and KEITH laughing with some other GUESTS.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Because human interest tends to be a euphemism for stories about vulnerable, weak-minded, ignorant, people to fill up the pages of newspapers read by vulnerable, weak- minded, ignorant people. (Suddenly realising how this sounds) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN (cont'd) Not that you are and, um, I hope you find him... He takes his wine and walks off, taking a swig. JANE look totally nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking his doctor’s words to heart MARTIN, up with the la jogs along a deserted street in a faded old ‘Spartak Mosc football jersey and shorts (from his time there), and bra new white trainers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A recital. A congregation watches a choir singing John Taverner’s ‘Mother of God’; music fills the beautiful interior. MARTIN sits with wife KATE, petite, pretty, Scottish. Next to her is ROBERT, Martin’s doctor, and his wife. Whilst everyone else appears to be enjoying the mus MARTIN is fidgety and distracted, unable to take comfort pleasure from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SFX: the music continues over: MARTIN is now outside; a thoughtful, profile shot, breath condensing in the cold air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN sits on the edge of his bed in his boxers and a T- Shirt. Behind him his wife KATE finishes moisturizing her hands before taking her dressing gown off and getting int bed. All the while we stay on MARTIN, wrestling with hims KATE gets into bed and sees that MARTIN has become frozen

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Finally) I don’t believe in God. And I don’t know when I stopped. A beat, then KATE makes her way over to his side of the b realising that her husband is deeply unhappy. She puts he arms around him from behind, comforting him.  17. MARTIN (cont'd) And I don’t know why it bothers me... Should I do a human interest story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP on an overweight mobile phone SALESMAN picking through some ribs. Amongst other lunch time customers, al whom are very probably not interested in Russian history, FIND MARTIN standing waiting in the reception area, watch with faint disgust as the phone SALESMAN licks his finger MARTIN looks out of the entrance doors, his face reflecte the glass. He looks at his watch, ponders on why he’s her and not at all sure it’s a good idea. He glances out of t doors again... and he sees her. PHILOMENA, walking across car park towards him, JANE by her side. His ghostly reflection in the glass is super-imposed over her for a moment... Curiosity aroused, he strains to get a good look - but ge only intermittent glimpses as a couple cars drive past on their way out of the car park. He notes she’s dressed sma - presumably for his benefit - and looks nervous. As she finally enters the restaurant he smiles and steps forward greet her:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hello I’m Martin, you must be Philomena.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Hello Martin. They shake hands; he notes the crucifix around her neck, in turn sneaks a look at him as he greets JANE.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (To JANE) Hello again. He gestures into the restaurant. MARTIN (cont'd) Table’s through here... He starts to lead them towards their table. MARTIN (cont'd) (To JANE) Sorry if I was a little rude the other night, caught me at a bad moment...  18.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m just glad you managed to track me down. Hope you didn’t mind meeting here but it’s mum’s favourite.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh no it’s... nice. They all sit down. MARTIN (cont'd) So how are you Philomena?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I’m all right. I had a new hip last year Martin, it’s much better than the bone one I had before and it’s made of ti-tanium which is metal - but it doesn’t rust.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well if that happened you’d have to have it oiled like the Tin Man wouldn’t you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh is that right?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No no - I mean, like the Wizard of Oz. PHILOMENA turns to JANE.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What does he mean?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He’s just joking mum.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It was just a joke. No, actually my mother has advanced osteoarthritis in both her knees. PHILOMENA laughs out loud. JANE realises that Martin is n now joking - and tries to move the whole thing on.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Shall we get some salad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN and PHILOMENA are at one end of the salad bar, JAN the other.  19.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Jane's the clever one in our family. She went to university as a mature student - you know, when you're quite old. Where did you go Martin - Oxbridge I’1l bet.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oxford yes.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I could tell you weren’t a duffer.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Helping himself to some salad) Been a while since I’ve been in a Harvester.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Do they not have them in London?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No I tend to go to a little local place, near where I live.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: And where’s that?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Knightsbridge.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh well that’1l be expensive. She sprinkles some bacon bits and croutons on her salad. Suddenly, PHILOMENA (cont'd) I like these little bits of toast on mine... (Beat) And are you married Martin?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. I am. I have a wife, Kate.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well that’s good. That’s grand... PHILOMENA reaches out and puts her hand on his. PHILOMENA (cont'd) I did love him, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. BABIES’ DORMITORY - DAY (FORMERLY SCENE 22) A long line of babies in cots. Two NUNS tend over them.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I disappeared from the world. My family didn’t visit me, and out of shame my father told everyone that I was dead. After you’d had your baby you had to stay in the Abbey for four years, totally cut off from the outside world. In order to repay the sisters for taking you in, you had to work. The sheer number of infants, their cots lined up with military precision, drives home the message about Roscrea that it is a place that deals in babies.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LAUNDRY, ROSCREA —- DAY The Abbey laundry; swirling steam, clattering noise. Watc over by YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE and two other NUNS, ‘fall GIRLS work loading clothing and bedding into boiling tubs water; or put wet laundry through huge mangles then hang out to dry on overhead lines.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The worst jobs were in the laundry, and that’s where they put me. I worked there seven days a week, the whole time I was there. They took in washing from miles around and charged for the service. We weren't paid a penny. I worked there with my best friend Kathleen. We find YOUNG PHILOMENA amongst them, dressed in a shapel pinafore, working over a boiling tub. Next to her is KATHLEEN, a pale faced young woman of roughly the same ag It's arduous, physically demanding work and YOUNG PHILOME and KATHLEEN, though worn out, try to keep each other’s spirits up with smiles of encouragement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA, KATHLEEN and three other GIRLS from the laundry, having finished their shift, hurry along a corri They pass Mother BARBARA, going in the opposite direction

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We were allowed to see our children for an hour a day, that was all.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER BARBARA
dialogues.text: Walk don’t run! The GIRLS immediately slow, walking round the next corner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls come into the nursery, walk towards camera. Big smiles on their faces, they crouch and hold their arms ou As we HOLD on them, FROM BEHIND CAMERA, five little CHILD aged between two and three, rush past us into their mothe arms. We pick out YOUNG PHILOMENA... her little boy ANTHO dark-haired, now three - the same age as the photo - runs into her arms. She hugs him tight, swinging him around, totally in love.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DAY NURSERY, ROSCREA — DUSK A little later. YOUNG PHILOMENA is sitting with KATHLEEN. They watch ANTHONY flying a toy aeroplane and holding the hand of Kathleen’s little daughter MARY, aged two, as the walk about together. The little girl reaches to take Anthony’s aeroplane and he lets her, without protest. She flies it about, just like he did.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Anthony was best friends with Kathleen’s daughter Mary - he’d even let her fly his little toy aeroplane. True love! The two of them were inseparable. The MOTHERS and CHILDREN are watched over by ANUNCIATA an another NUN, sitting together. YOUNG PHILOMENA and ANUNCI exchange a secret smile - but she can’t talk to her whils the other NUN is there, it’s not allowed.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (to KATHLEEN) Look at that, he won’t let her out of his sight. KATHLEEN doesn’t answer; YOUNG PHILOMENA sees she is anxi worried.  22.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: (In a sudden rush) Oh Phil the girls in the kitchen said Mother Barbara had Mary up at the house today - what do you think she wanted with her? YOUNG PHILOMENA’S turns this over in her mind, but presen comforting face to her KATHLEEN.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I’m sure it’s nothing to worry about Kath.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We lived with it every day. Who’s child would be taken next? YOUNG PHILOMENA sees the other NUN leave the room, and se the opportunity to go and talk to ANUNCIATA.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (To KATHLEEN) I won’t be a minute. She goes over to ANUNCIATA , sits down next to her and ta in a quiet voice:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Kathleen’s worried sick. She thinks they’re going to take Mary away from her. I said if they were going to do that they’d tell her first for sure... ANUNCIATA is caught between a rock and a hard place. She’ just a young girl herself, and she doesn’t know how to de with the enormity of what she knows will happen to most o the girls at the abbey. So she clumsily tries to move the conversation on, and pulls something from her robe.

dialogues.speaker: ANUNCIATA
dialogues.text: (Keeping her voice down) I got something for you Phil, but you can’t tell anyone about it. She hands YOUNG PHILOMENA a small, black and white photograph. She gasps: it is of Anthony, clutching his aeroplane, looking shyly at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: ANUNCIATA
dialogues.text: He’s growing up so fast.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh thank you...  23. ANUNCIATA (cont'd) I'll bet his father was handsome.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: He was. How did you... [GET THIS]

dialogues.speaker: ANUNCIATA
dialogues.text: (Beat) I borrowed a Box Brownie and took it when Reverend Mother wasn’t looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA, now at the table with MARTIN and JANE, holds t same photo, the one Jane saw her clutching the night she finally confessed all, now in a small leather case. PHILO passes it to MARTIN, who studies it.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Whenever I look at that, I think about Anthony but I say a little prayer for Anunciata, who saved his life when I gave birth to him. She died a long time ago... if she hadn’t taken that, I’d have nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So... you were just trapped there the whole time?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: The only way you could leave was if you paid them a hundred pounds. But where would I get that kind of money? And where would I go? On PHILOMENA, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA is back at work in the laundry.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It happened about a week later. I remember that day so clearly. As she starts to heave a heavy laundry bag over to a tub hears, outside, SFX tyres crunching on gravel. At this so the GIRLS exchange looks, a feeling of dread settling ove them. KATHLEEN starts to shake with fear.  24.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We all knew what it meant when a big car arrived. Kathleen was inconsolable. She knew this time they’d come for Mary. YOUNG PHILOMENA looks around and sees that, temporarily, YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE and one of the other nuns have disappeared - there is only one NUN left, who has her bac her. YOUNG PHILOMENA abandons her duties and crosses to a small basement window high up in the wall. Standing on tiptoes, she sees, beyond a hedge, a dreaded shiny black limousine drive past. KATHLEEN looks up at her piteously, pleadingly. YOUNG PHILOMENA catches the eye of another GI who shakes her head - ‘Don’t do it...’ - but ignores her checking that the NUN is still distracted, quickly darts through a back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA emerges alone into a small courtyard, cro to the far side and peers through some gates fencing her from the outside world. Foliage half obscures some well- heeled FIGURES getting out of the limousine - a thirty- something woman in a fur coat and a man in a Cashmere coa and Homburg hat.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As soon as I saw their lovely clothes, and Mother Barbara so happy and smiling, I knew all hope was gone. She watches as they are greeted at the main entrance by a fawning and uncharacteristically gregarious Mother BARBAR Then, from behind:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come away from there! She turns, scalded, and there is YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I... I had a stomach ache, Sister Hidegarde. It’s my time of the month.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: Well... you’re not unique in that regard. Put your mind to your work and it’1l pass.  25. PHILOMENA retreats miserably to the laundry - she now kno all hope has gone for Kathleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that afternoon. YOUNG PHILOMENA is buttoning up her pinafore as she stands at a window.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Kathleen cried so hard they took her to the sick bay and gave her brandy. But her fate was sealed. YOUNG PHILOMENA looks down through the window and we...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: .+. her POV. From her vantage point she looks down across courtyard, through a window, into the nursery. She can se little MARY but, because of the angle she is looking down from and the height of the window frame, she can only see bottom halves of four adults who surround the little girl Mother BARBARA and YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE - identifiable from their unflattering skirts and shoes - are presenting MARY to the couple we saw earlier, the woman recognizable from her fur coat and heels; the man from his pressed trousers and polished shoes. MARY looks up at them wide-e frightened.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Phil, it’s choir practice. YOUNG PHILOMENA lingers on the scene below for a few more moments, horribly fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND, (OOV)
dialogues.text: You’1l be in trouble if you don’t go... Reluctantly, YOUNG PHILOMENA turns and follows the FRIEND out. But we STAY on the view and see what she misses: ANT runs into shot, holds MARY’S hand and looks up at the adu

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They’d only come for Mary. But Anthony wouldn’t let her out of his sight. They were inseparable, you see...  26. The WOMAN crouches down to ANTHONY’S level and touches hi face tenderly. But, because she has her back to us, we st don’t see her face. We don’t need to, she simply represen money. A customer. The WOMAN takes the hands of both chil and leads them away. Over this we hear, incoming from the next scene, the CHOIR SINGING...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA sings in the chapel. She is with other MAGDALEN GIRLS on one row of pews; the NUNS, strictly segregated on another row, facing them.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Normally, I loved to sing - it was one of the only things I enjoyed at that place. But all I could think about was poor Kathleen. We can see YOUNG PHILOMENA’S heart isn’t in it, her expression far off, her mind elsewhere. She sees ANUNCIAT enter the chapel and take her place with the NUNS. She catches her friend’s eye and manages to throw her a smile But ANUNCIATA, hollow-eyed, is unable to return it. YOUNG PHILOMENA sees tears in her friend’s eyes - she’s crying? Assuming she must also be upset about Kathleen, YOUNG PHILOMENA carries on as the hymn builds to a crescendo. But now a MAGDALEN GIRL enters the chapel and hurries to the others. She pushes through until she’s next to YOUNG PHILOMENA, then urgently whispers in her ear. The blood drains from YOUNG PHILOMENA’S face; panic-stricken she pu her way to the end of the pew. ANUNCIATA watches her go, agonized expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA runs from the chapel along a curving wall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA runs through a door and up two flights of stairs as fast as she can, hyperventilating. She turns in room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A window: YOUNG PHILOMENA climbs up so she can see throug the clear glass.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Her POV. Outside the front door, ANTHONY and MARY are shepherded i the big shiny car by Mother BARBARA. The MAN’S face is obscured as he gets into the driver’s seat; the WOMAN, st with her back to us, shakes hands with Mother BARBARA. ANTHONY is wearing a smart, sky blue woollen coat and clutches his tin aeroplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From down on the ground looking up, we hear YOUNG PHILOME muffled scream:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Anthony! We see her banging on the window. ANTHONY looks round as he heard something, before climbing into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANTHONY looks through the rear window of the car, his eye are scanning. He doesn’t see YOUNG PHILOMENA at the upper floor window, banging and screaming inaudibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA is now overtaken by animal instinct. She lioness in headlong flight, determined to save her young. a frenetic, taut sequence she leaps down flights of stair along a corridor and out through a door. Her focus absolu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA bursts into the courtyard only to see the tail lights of the shiny car disappearing from sight over rise. She is too late. She stares after it, then sinks to knees on the gravel drive, weeping. Anthony is gone. She cries out in utter anguish, a shriek from deep inside her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE, inside the Abbey, looks out upon hearing this cry and see the distraught, broken YOUNG PHILOMENA. The older woman digests the scene for a moment then callously moves on.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: YOUNG PHILOMENA sinks to her knees in the courtyard, sobb uncontrollably, surrounded by brightly coloured flower be alone in her grief.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was wearing a beautiful blue duffel coat, that’s what I remember most of all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN and JANE watch PHILOMENA, spellbound. MARTIN has a open and has been making notes as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I couldn't have given him a coat like that.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I think what they did to you was evil.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No I don’t like that word.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No - evil’s good. (They stare at him) Story wise. He jots down more notes in his pad.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Some of them were nice.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It was a breech birth and they wouldn't even give her painkillers.  29.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Great... Again - story wise. (Trying to move on) So can we go and talk to these nuns?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You can try, maybe you’1ll have more luck than mum’s had.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I've been several times over the years to ask where he was. They were very helpful - it’s not like it used to be. They said they'd try and trace him for me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: But they haven’t?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Can you help me find him Martin?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Shutting his pad) Well, it’s certainly an interesting story.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m taking mum to Ireland next week for a few days - why don’t you come along with us and you can visit Roscrea with her?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh yes there’s plenty of room - it’s a Vauxhall Cavalier.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh no, it’s no problem, I'll... I’ll fly over. Slightly embarrassed smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO SOUND. December 1955. ANTHONY, 3, and little MARY, des the steps of a Pan Am Constellation aircraft. The jerky images show them setting foot on the tarmac. ANTHONY is wearing the blue coat and clutching his plane. He holds h with MARY, both of them looking forlorn.  30. We are aware of them being lined up so that somebody (out shot) can take a photo of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soft, rolling fields of the Irish countryside. A BMW series speeds along a country road. In the distance, high hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN looks at the scenery with interest as it flashes p shiny modern bungalows interspersed with the occasional abandoned stone cottage; the scars of Ireland’s past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN negotiates a bend and enters the village of Birr. little High Street is typically Irish, the shop fronts painted in bright blues, oranges, pinks and turquoises. A cross-roads beside Molloy’s Bar, obviously a prearranged rendezvous point, stand PHILOMENA and JANE. He pulls up alongside them and JANE opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA/ JANE
dialogues.text: Hello Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hello, sorry I’m a little late. JANE helps PHILOMENA into the passenger seat. MARTIN (cont'd) Bit of trouble with the hire car.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (As she gets in) Oh it’s lovely, isn’t it Jane. I can see why you wouldn’t want to squash up with us in the Cavalier.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It wasn’t that it was just... hada few things to do.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don’t want me to come with you mum?  31. See MARTIN, slightly panic-stricken.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You’re not coming?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No - I told Jane we'll be fine on our own, just the two of us, isn’t that right Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Fixed smile) Yes. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’ve put some things in your bag. PHILOMENA starts to look through her bag, pulling out a packet Custard Creams and a tube of Tunes. JANE (cont'd) Good luck, I’1l see you tonight. (Smiles for MARTIN) Thanks Martin. MARTIN returns the smile, JANE shuts the door. He pulls a

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What kind of car is this?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s a BMW.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: That’s German. (Beat, opens a packet) Would you like a Tune Martin?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Trying to make a joke) If I hum it, will you play it? She obviously doesn’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No, would you like a Tune? He decides to let it go.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Thank you. He takes a Tune from the pack, unwraps it and pops it in mouth.  32. As he’s doing this, PHILOMENA takes a St. Christopher fro the bag and hangs it on the vent in the dash board; MARTI watches as she pats it.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: For good luck.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He was always my favourite Saint, Christopher. (Little smile) Resisting those two beautiful women sent to tempt him.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Do you believe in God Martin?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well, where do you start. That’s a very difficult question to answer, isn’t it... Erm... do you?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BMW. ROSCREA ABBEY. DAY
dialogues.text: The two of them suck Tunes as they enter Roscrea, the Abb getting closer. MARTIN sneaks a look at PHILOMENA but she doesn’t appear to be unduly anxious. The car comes up the drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BMW pulls up outside the Abbey building and MARTIN he PHILOMENA out. They gaze up: the Abbey looks cleaner, som more sterile - but it’s still the same oppressive, pebble dashed monolith set in acres of ground.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I’m fine. PHILOMENA leads the way up to the front door. She pauses a moment outside: PHILOMENA (cont’d) I’m one of the lucky ones Martin. Some of the mothers and babies didn’t even survive the childbirth.  33. As we see this hit home with MARTIN, PHILOMENA presses th buzzer and, after a few moments, a YOUNG AFRICAN NUN - dressed much less formally than her 1950s counterparts in blue sweater and white blouse - opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I’m Philomena Lee. I made an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: Oh yes come in Philomena.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: And this is my friend Martin Sixsmith News At Ten.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: Oh, hello.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (As they enter) BBC news actually, but not any more.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MEETING ROOM, ROSCREA —- DAY They are shown into a formal room reserved for sister Claire's official meetings, with a low table and chairs. There is some iconography prominent on the walls, includi some Madonnas and a wooden crucifix with a brightly paint figure of Jesus in red loin cloth, blood pouring from stigmata wounds and a sword wound to his side.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: Sister Claire will be with you shortly. Would you like some tea?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh yes please.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Yes please. Can I use the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: It’s down stairs on-

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I know where it is.  34. PHILOMENA leaves. MARTIN looks around, taking everything intrigued by some framed photographs of the Abbey ‘then a now’ on a section of wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA retraces her steps from all those years ago, cl some stairs and stands at the window where she last saw h child, fifty years before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN is looking at the photos on the wall... a head and shoulders photo from the early 60s of Mother Barbara and YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE on the Abbey steps, starched Wimp crucifixes around their necks; a nun holding a baby; two tending rows of cots (as in scene 22).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP: PHILOMENA, staring straight ahead. We stay on h for a while, her face set and thoughtful. Then we...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: «+. what she’s looking at: that same view from the courty she had fifty years ago. In her mind’s eye, it is just li it was yesterday, the car carrying Anthony disappearing f view over the rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN moves on to a Hollywood publicity photo of the mov star Jane Russell, busty and glamorous, looking incongruo amongst the faded pictures of nuns and children. The phot signed: ‘With much love’. On MARTIN, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA stands looking at the room where the laundry us to be. Behind her the window where she climbed up and saw posh car driving past.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MEETING ROOM, ROSCREA —- DAY MARTIN is being nosy, looking round the room. He stands a bay window and can see, through a window on the other sid a courtyard, in a corridor on the other side of a courtya they overlook, a very old nun standing with two sticks, staring at him (in fact, this is SISTER HILDEGARDE - thou we don’t know this yet).

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Hello, I’m sister Claire. Startled, he turns round. Sister CLAIRE is mid-40s, kind- faced. She smiles cheerfully; his eyes flick to the cruci she also wears.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, hello... He gestures back to the photos on the wall, trying to div her attention away from what he’s been looking at. MARTIN (cont'd) Just admiring your picture of Jayne Mansfield.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No that’s Jane Russell. Jayne Mansfield was the blonde one.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Of yes of course, I mean they were both very big - I mean the two of them, they were huge. Their careers. He can’t stop himself glancing down at Sister CLAIRE’S bu MARTIN (cont'd) Which one died in the car crash?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Jayne Mansfield, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She was decapitated wasn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t know the details. I’m sure it was horrible.  36.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Why is she on the wall?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Sorry, I didn’t catch your name?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Martin Sixsmith. PHILOMENA enters the waiting area.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Brightly) He’s Martin Sixsmith, News At Ten.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: BBC news actually. But I’m not with them any more.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Hello Philomena, very nice to meet you - ah, here’s the tea. The YOUNG NUN lays some tea things and a plate of fruit b down in front of them and leaves. As SISTER CLAIRE sets t tea and plates, MARTIN manoeuvres himself back to the bay window, sneaks a look sideways and sees the Old Nun (Sist HILDEGARDE) is still there. SISTER CLAIRE (cont'd) Now I was trying to find in our records the last time you came to see us Philomena?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: It was well before your time Sister Claire. Mother Barbara had passed away and I spoke to Sister Hildegarde on the telephone - but when I came here she wasn’t well enough to see me.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: She’s still with us, but she’s very frail now. She lays plates in front of PHILOMENA and MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh look Martin buttered brack. Have some. MARTIN helps himself to a slice; he takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Very tasty. It’s a bit like a sort of a Pandolce, isn’t it?  37. They just stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: It’s fruit bread Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, no it’s... yes that’s lovely.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Well now - I don’t know if they told you last time Philomena, but most of our records were destroyed in the big fire-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Fire?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: -it was before my time. So I’m afraid we're at a standstill.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I have no news. I’m so sorry we can’t help you. We can see how much of a blow this is to PHILOMENA, how m she'd built herself up.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes... The room falls silent. MARTIN watches as PHILOMENA starts speak, quietly at first but building in emotion. PHILOMENA (cont’d) I still go to mass... I don’t want to cause any fuss or point the finger at anyone, or blame the church in any way. I just want to know that he’s all right - I don’t even have to see him. Sometimes I have visions of him and he’s homeless and nobody loves him...

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (Takes PHILOMENA’S hand) Philomena we can’t take away your pain, but we can walk through it with you, hand in hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What about some of the older nuns? Perhaps they might remember a few details?  38.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Most of them have passed on.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What about the ones that haven’t?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Well I don’t think you’1l get much sense out of them.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Can I try? He sneaks another look and sees a curtain being drawn by someone in front of HILDEGARDE, so he can no longer see inside the room.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s going to be possible.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I’m happy to answer any questions that Philomena has.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m asking a question.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: You're a journalist.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I used to be, certainly.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Martin’s a Roman Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes... well, I used to be.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I'd feel more comfortable if I could speak to Philomena in private. MARTIN has rather enjoyed - for this brief moment - being journalist again. But, on catching PHILOMENA’S worried expression - she hates confrontation - he reins it back i beat then, politely:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Of course.  39. He gets up and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN shuts the door behind him, quietly seething at Sis Claire's obfuscating. He wanders over to the gift shop st and idly fingers a little plastic Jesus for a few moments but his mind is elsewhere. Checking he’s not being observ he crosses to some double doors and peers through them an sees the Old Nun (HILDEGARDE), on her sticks, silhouetted against the light from the open door behind her. Her eyes seem to meet his; her expression inscrutable. MARTIN smil He reaches to open the door. Then, from the staircase beh him:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Hello - can I help you? MARTIN spins round to see the YOUNG NUN.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sorry, I was just erm...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: Are you looking for something? He turns back, just as the door shuts; Sister HILDEGARDE gone, the light from the room extinguished. The momentary opening closed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Pointing to the door) Is that, erm..?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: Those are private quarters.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Right. (Beat) I‘ll wait outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN is standing in a little graveyard with neatly tend rows of irons crosses. As he walks along the graves he realises from the inscriptions, (Sister Theresa, Sister Margaret...), that nuns from the Abbey are buried here. Curious, he walks along until he finds Mother Barbara's grave, and notes she died on July 20th, 1990.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The YOUNG NUN sees a pale-faced PHILOMENA to the front do PHILOMENA clutches a manila envelope.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Thank you, and would you thank Sister Claire again for me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: Goodbye Philomena. The YOUNG NUN disappears back inside, shutting the door behind her and leaving PHILOMENA alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bit between his teeth, MARTIN climbs over a low fence into a small enclosed area adjacent to the nuns’ graveyar which is thoroughly overgrown with weeds, bushes and brambles. He crouches down, peers through the tangle and just make out a headstone. Using his feet and hands he cl away the overgrowth around it until he can see it properl and reads the inscription: ‘Maria Gidney’, a young woman died in 1962 aged 16, with underneath: ‘Mother And Child In Childbirth’...

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT TO
dialogues.text: He uses a stick to clear away bracken from another headst he reads: ‘Aisling Devlin’, who died in 1957 aged only 14 And again, underneath: ‘Mother And Child Died In Childbir He stands up, surveys the overgrown graveyard and the nun graveyard next to it, and the thought hits him: ‘Why are graves of the nuns beautifully tended, and yet the graves the mothers and children abandoned and overgrown?’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN hurries back to his car, where PHILOMENA is waitin for him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sorry I was just having a look around... (Seeing her expression) Are you okay? PHILOMENA, obviously upset, doesn’t reply; she just wants get into the car as quickly as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA sits staring ahead. MARTIN doesn’t start the ca

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What did she say to you?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Long beat) She said you were a journalist and you were trying to manipulate me and I should be careful what I say to you. She opens her bag, takes out the manila envelope, hands i MARTIN. PHILOMENA (cont'd) And she gave me this.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Do you want me to open it? Again she doesn’t reply. He opens it, takes out a single sheet of paper - obviously a photocopy. He scans it. MARTIN (cont'd) It’s a contract... signed by you, in 1955. (Reading from it) They’ve highlighted part of it... (Quotes) ‘I hereby relinquish full claim forever to my said child- PHILOMENA takes up the passage, quoting verbatim from mem

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Taking over) -said child Anthony Lee, and I further undertake never to attempt to see, interfere with or make any claim to the said child at any future time...’ Silence. PHILOMENA (cont’d) I‘ll never find him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If they coerced you in any way to sign that piece of paper we can challenge them legally.  42.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (With a heavy heart) No-one forced me Martin. I signed of my own free will.

dialogues.speaker: NO SOUND. A
dialogues.text: aged eight, little boy. back garden with a hose.

dialogues.speaker: ST LOUIS
dialogues.text: summer’s day, 1960. ANTHONY is growing up. Now he is no longer recognisable as Philomena’s He has a family and OLDER BROTHERS. He is in the with them - two of them are spraying each other ANTHONY is holding a baseball bat; a ball is tossed to him, he takes a huge swipe and misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BMW is parked by a dry stone wall; MARTIN and PHILOME are walking countryside back up a field towards the car. Gently rolling and green fields lead to some high hills.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Funny isn’t it, how every piece of paper that might be able to help you has been destroyed. But guess what? The one piece of paper designed to stop you from finding him has been lovingly preserved. God in His infinite wisdom decided to spare that from the flames.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I signed it because I believed I'd committed a terrible sin Martin, and I had to be punished. And... what made it so much worse, was that I enjoyed it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: The sex. He turns to face her. PHILOMENA (cont’d) Oh, it was wonderful. I thought I was floating on air. He was so handsome and the way he held me in his arms and - well I didn’t even know I had a clitoris Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Really?  43.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: And after I had the sex, I thought anything that feels so lovely must be wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Mutters ) Fucking Catholics. (Realizes what he’s said) Sorry. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I spent thirty years as a nurse, I’ve heard worse than that.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s just that, why would God bestow on us a sexual desire which he then wants us to resist? Is it some weird game that he’s invented to alleviate the boredom of being omnipotent? Baffles me... and I thought I was pretty clever. They fall quiet; she stares out at the view.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well maybe you’re not. He looks at her; smiles to himself at how sharply she gav good as she got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE walks in to the bar to find MARTIN and PHILOMENA sit on stools at the bar, looking a little glum. She has a sh in front of her, he a pint of Guinness - both almost finished.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How did it go?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What, from the Sisters of Little Mercy?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Laughs ) Just tea and cake then. That’s all they’ve ever given mum.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t their fault Jane, they had a fire and all the records were lost. The BARMAN puts a new glass of sherry in front of PHILOME

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No more please - it’s past your bedtime.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: There’s got to be some other way of approaching this- PHILOMENA picks up the sherry.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Mum!

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well he’s poured it now. JANE rolls her eyes; PHILOMENA knocks it back in two gulp PHILOMENA (cont'd) Night Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Good night Philomena. Night Jane. They exchange a smile, then they leave. MARTIN reflects o things for a few moments. The BARMAN, early 40s, puts ano pint of Guinness down in front of him, MARTIN runs a fing down the side of it.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Been up to the Abbey?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, it’s obviously changed a lot. Different nuns there now, not the same ones they had when the Magdalen girls were there. From out the back:

dialogues.speaker: MUM, (OOV)
dialogues.text: They’re all gone now! MARTIN flicks a look in the direction the voice came from but the BARMAN ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: We've had a few staying here, trying to find what happened to their sons or daughters. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARMAN (cont'd) There’s not many of them gets any joy from there.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I imagine that’s because of the fire? The one that destroyed everything?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sure it is.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How did that start - do you know?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: I should think they put a match to it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: The Sisters. Sure they had a great fire out the back in the field.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So... the building wasn’t damaged?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: They had a fuckin’ big bonfire, burnt all the records. Thousands of ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: This was years ago. I suppose they were embarrassed about selling all them babies to America. From out the back again:

dialogues.speaker: MUM, (OOV)
dialogues.text: They don’t want people telling tales.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: That’s me mother.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You say they were sold to Americans?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: A lot of the Yanks came over to Ireland to look for babies. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARMAN (cont'd) They were the only ones who could afford them.

dialogues.speaker: MUM, (OOV)
dialogues.text: A thousand pounds. Now the MUM emerges from the back; she’s mid-60s, stout. MUM (cont'd) Jane Russell bought a baby. From Derry, in 1952.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That’s unbelievable... babies were sold?

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: They said she came in here and asked for Bourbon but they had to give her a glass of Paddy instead. But I’m not one to repeat gossip.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, no... I can see that. As she says this MARTIN finds his eye resting on a ‘Madon and Child’ above the optics. MARTIN (cont'd) So how did they decide who got a baby?

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: If you were a Catholic with a thousand pounds you could buy a baby. Jane Russell bought one to take home with her. But my lips are sealed on the subject...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARTIN’S ROOM, GUEST HOUSE - DAWN MARTIN works at his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN has gone for another jog, by the dry stone wall an field with the distant high hills from earlier. He seems energized this morning, bounding along like a spring lamb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MARTIN’S ROOM, GUEST HOUSE - DAWN MARTIN paces around his chintzy little room speaking on h mobile.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: «+. yes, well you said to give you a ring if I found something Sally, and it just fell into my lap really. He sits on the edge of a cheap attempt at a four-poster b ducking under the burgundy fringe hanging from it. MARTIN (cont'd) Hope it’s not too late but I’ve got myself pretty fired up - I think there are some interesting themes, people tracing their family trees... the whole Irish Diaspora...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Mitchell has a glass fronted office looking out ont hi-tech, open-plan newsroom dotted with JOURNALISTS worki the night shift. SALLY is pouring herself a coffee from a percolator as she speaks to Martin; from the paper and me scattered across her desk it’s been a busy day.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Don’t use words like Diaspora Martin. I can’t spell it and people don’t know what it means. [INTERCUT between these two scenes]

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well, it just means-

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: No no - I’m genuinely not interested in what it means. She pours two sugar sachets into her coffee. SALLY (cont'd) Who are the goodies, who are the baddies? Her direct manner wrong foots him for a moment.  48.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Erm... okay, it’s about a little old Irish lady, retired nurse, trying to find her baby son who was taken... ripped away from her at birth, by... (Suddenly comes to him) «+. evil nuns. SALLY looks around for a stirrer, can’t find one so uses finger.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: So how does it end? (Before he can answer) -and it’s got to be really happy or really sad. What I don’t want is some in-the-middle bullshit, yeh?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well... what I’d suggest is an emotional reunion. It’ll cost a little bit in flights and hotels, but we win either way. We find out he’s the chairman of IBM, or he’s a hobo - hooray or boo-hoo - doesn’t matter. ‘The years melted away as a fifty year silence was broken with two simple words: ‘Hello mum’.’ I could write it now.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you were so cynical.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’ve been practising.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (Pause to sip her coffee) Okay, do it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Not quite believing it) Really?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: My assistant will call tomorrow to make the arrangements - and no bar bills.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Thanks Sally, I really appreciate... He realises she’s already hung up. But he smiles to himse nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA, MARTIN and JANE sit at a table having breakfas MARTIN, now in full-on journalist mode, has his laptop op and consults an A4 pad full of scrawled notes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: -I am almost certain that Anthony was taken to America after he was adopted. The Abbey seems to have dealt exclusively with American customers.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Customers? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Taking a sip of his tea) They were the only ones who could afford the fee. She still looks confused so MARTIN clarifies things. MARTIN (cont'd) Anthony was sold.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Outraged) But... that’s appalling.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: They were trying to give hima better life.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: They were making money out of him! A beat; they’re all silent for a moment. MARTIN takes a b of his soda bread.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I got through to the Sacred Heart Adoption Society in Cork first thing this morning, but they just referred me to the Irish Adoption Board, who referred me back to the Sacred Heart Adoption Society.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Sending you round in circles!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes - but I spoke to a few contacts from my Washington days last night, and there are avenues that can be pursued there. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN (cont'd) The stumbling block, of course, is that I can only get so far doing things on your behalf Philomena. But as you’re his mother, they are duty bound to provide you with the information. Silence. PHILOMENA and JANE absorb this for a few moments

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Are you suggesting my mother goes to America with you?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Nervous, but trying to sound ‘casual’ ) If she wanted to. My editor has agreed to pay for flights and hotels for the two of us.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Turning to PHILOMENA) How would you feel about that, going to America?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. MARTIN can’t resist a little bit of salesmanship.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: All I'd say is it’s an amazing opportunity Philomena. PHILOMENA turns this over in her mind. She looks at JANE; then MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I could come with you if you like?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No no no - you’ve got your work. I’m more worried about Martin going all that way with a daft old Irish lady like me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t think you're daft... or old.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh go’way with you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well maybe a little bit. He says this as a joke but it doesn’t land quite as he intended - PHILOMENA looks a little offended for a moment  51.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I'd like to go. I want to know if he’s ever thought about me, ‘cos I’ve thought about him every day... OUT on MARTIN, silently euphoric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We establish the busy concourse: noise, movement, bustle. Amongst this we FIND PHILOMENA and MARTIN at a check-in d MARTIN is heaving their cases onto the conveyor belt.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN OPERATOR
dialogues.text: Can I have your passports please? MARTIN produces his passport from his jacket; PHILOMENA searches for hers in her wheelie. CHECK-IN OPERATOR (cont'd) Did you pack your baggage yourself?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No. (They both look at her) My daughter helped me.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN OPERATOR
dialogues.text: (Moving on) And has anybody asked you to carry any items with you on board?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No. (Beat) Well, yes. The CHECK-IN OPERATOR looks up. PHILOMENA (cont’d) But the person who asked me is known to me. And the items are non... explosive.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Has Jane given you some Custard Creams? She nods; MARTIN turns to the CHECK-IN OPERATOR.  52. MARTIN (cont'd) They’re just some biscuits from her daughter. The CHECK-IN OPERATOR starts to print off their tickets. MARTIN speaks quietly to PHILOMENA. MARTIN (cont'd) There are certain key words in airports that can be quite... alarming. Erm, gun, bomb, hostage, Allah Akbar. And... explosive, I would say, is definitely one of those words.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Even if you say, ‘non explosive’?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Even then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO SOUND. 1962. CLOSE-UP, blurry image, of a sparkler fiz away in the darkness; we see nothing else. The cake is carried through to the dining table, ten candles being li it as it is carried. The cake is put down on the table an the camera re-positions itself until the cake is between and the (as yet) unseen little boy. He blows the candles The light switch is flipped and now we see him. ANTHONY. has grown into a serious-faced, thoughtful ten-year-old. There is something sad about his expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA and MARTIN climb onto a mobility vehicle, compl with flashing lights and warning beeps, to be driven by a AIRPORT WORKER to their gate.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well I’m getting the royal treatment here Martin. I feel like the Pope. They pass other PASSENGERS making the journey on foot, MA feeling slightly self-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This’ll save your hip.  53. She’s holding her book, a romantic novel entitled ‘The Slipper And The Horseshoe’, in her hands. She sees him pu his book - a weighty tome about Tsar Nicholas - out from shoulder bag.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Is that an interesting book Martin - I’ve just finished mine. She brandishes ‘The Slipper And The Horseshoe’.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s er... about Tsarist Russia and the October revolution and... it’s a bit dull you know, it’s all just political horse-trading really...

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Mine was about horses too. It was about this fella Robert and he’s engaged to this duchess and he’s the son of a doctor so he’s done very well for himself but this woman oh she’s terrible this duchess is vain as you like and forever looking in the mirror and all the rest of it. And she thinks he’s dull as ditch-water so he takes up an interest in the horses so he fits in with all the upper classes and well of course he meets the girl down the stables and she’s not even a doctor’s daughter her father’s just a farmhand and he only has one foot but anyway of course they fall in love, so the duchess you’re thinking be careful what you wish for and he’s now torn between becoming a duke because when he marries her he’ll become lord of the manor and all that sort of thing, and the stable girl who he loves but hasn’t a penny to her name her brothers have no shoes on their feet.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Trying to cut in) That sounds great.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The vehicle rounds a corner; PHILOMENA is still in full f MARTIN trapped next to her.  54.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: -so the big day’s coming, the wedding and she, oh she’s a lovely, lovely girl, she says Robert has to do his duty and he’s spoken for and of course he’s being measured up for his suit but you can tell his heart’s not in it he’s all the while thinking about the horses and the stable girl. And they’re all there waiting for him in the church, the hoi polloi, but the thing is Martin this duchess she just wants Robert to spite the fella she’s really after but towards the end the duchess finds out that the stable girl has designs on Robert and the father without the foot dies but before he does he says to Robert ‘follow your heart’ and then the duchess gives the stable girl her marching orders and she packs her things - there’s a pony and trap waiting for her outside and when she climbs into it she asks do you know where we’re going? And the driver turns round and if it isn’t yer man Robert. And he says ‘I’m taking you to a place where no-one can hurt you anymore’.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT: the buggy sails on serenely towards the gate, PHILOMENA and MARTIN getting smaller in frame as they get further and further away. PHILOMENA (cont‘d) Well, I didn’t see that coming Martin, not in a million years.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No... no it’s nice to have a surprise. Sounds like a real page turner.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: You can borrow it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh no really-

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Come on I’ve just finished it now.  55.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Weakly) -I almost feel like I’ve read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA and MARTIN sit together as PASSENGERS board all around them. A HOSTESS offers them a tray of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Champagne or Buck’s Fizz?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Following his lead) No thank you. The HOSTESS moves on. MARTIN tips PHILOMENA off:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: They’re free.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Immediately calls out) I say! I'll have a Buck's Fizz! The HOSTESS turns back to her and she takes a Buck’s Fizz PHILOMENA (cont’d) Thank you. (Takes a sip) Oo, that’s lovely. (To MARTIN, impressed) You have to pay for everything on Ryan Air.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Martin! MARTIN looks up and sees he’s been spotted by ALEX, (smar dressed slightly younger than Martin), who’s standing in First Class Cabin putting something in the overhead locke He walks through to Club World to say hello.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Awkward) Alex, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Not seen you since you... left the department. I was gonna call you actually... ALEX'S eyes flick across to PHILOMENA, wondering who she  56. ALEX (cont'd) Still friends?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes of course.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Listen, I hope you didn’t think I dropped you in it?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Honestly, it doesn’t matter - fog of war.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeh, collateral damage. (Beat) So what are you up to - off to the primaries? ALEX looks again at PHILOMENA who is waiting, looking slightly confused, to be introduced.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yeh-

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No - he’s helping me look for my-
