dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Cutting her off) -it’s a human interest story. Human interest...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (Sensing the awkwardness) Oh. Well good luck with it... I'd better scoot back. ALEX goes back into the First Class Cabin, MARTIN smiling until he’s out of sight - then the smile disappears. PHILOMENA leans across.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Martin should we pretend we don’t know each other?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No no it’s just him, he’s a nosy... nuisance. She thinks about this, then points:

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Is that First Class in there?  57.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Slightly acid) Yes. It’s a perk of the job.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Just because you’re in first class it doesn’t make you a first class person.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He’s all right... A long pause, PHILOMENA takes a sip of her Buck’s Fizz, MARTIN opens his book. She leans in again, speaks quietly

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I think he needs a good smack in the chops. MARTIN laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I think you're probably right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several hours into the flight. MARTIN is dozing with his blanket over him; most of the other passengers are asleep too. PHILOMENA catches her reflection in the window and w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STILL NO SOUND. 1966. A school production of ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’. MICHAEL, (Anthony), now 14, is up on stag playing ‘Puck’. This is a different, more confident MICHA heavily made up, dancing around on stage in a loin cloth; so confident, authoritative, obviously loving it. We will realise later that he is exploring his sexuality. On stage, TITANIA, LYSANDER and HERMIA sleep. Enter PUCK.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (AS PUCK)
dialogues.text: Through the forest have I gone. But Athenian found I none, On whose eyes I might approve This flower's force in stirring love. Night and silence.--Who is here? Weeds of Athens he doth wear: This is he, my master said, Despised the Athenian maid; And here the maiden, sleeping sound, On the dank and dirty ground. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL (AS PUCK) (cont'd) Pretty soul! she durst not lie Near this lack-love, this kill courtesy. Churl, upon thy eyes I throw All the power this charm doth owe. When thou wakest, let love forbid Sleep his seat on thy eyelid: So awake when I am gone; For I must now to Oberon. PUCK exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheels hit the tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seatbelt sign is switched off with a ‘ping’. PASSENGE jump up out of their seats and start to grab their bags f the overhead lockers. PHILOMENA gets up too, but MARTIN s seated - engrossed in ‘The Slipper and the Horseshoe’.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Martin can you help me with my bag? (No answer) Martin?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Without looking up) One second... He wants to finish his page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance the Capitol. A taxi pulls into the Hotel forecourt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Philomena enter the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN makes his way along the corridor to pay a visit on Philomena in her room. He finds the right room number and knocks. PHILOMENA answers, excited, and welcomes him in:

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Martin, did you have a chocolate on your pillow?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PHILOMENA’S ROOM, WASHINGTON DC HOTEL - NIGHT She leads him over to the balcony:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: How the other half live, eh? They walk out onto the balcony and she gestures to a nigh time view of the city. PHILOMENA (cont'd) And look at that view.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mine is of the heating ducts... His phone rings; he checks the display and takes the call MARTIN (cont'd) Oo - Caroline from the records office. He stays out on the balcony and PHILOMENA comes back insi to give him some privacy. As he paces up and down outside the phone, PHILOMENA sits on the bed and presses a few buttons - ending in an on-screen movie menu. She puts her glasses on and flicks through the movie summaries, gettin more and more impressed as she reads them. Finally, MARTI comes back in from the balcony. He looks around for some wood to touch - but can’t see an MARTIN (cont'd) Shall we go for a walk, try and shake off our jet lag? You said you wanted to see the Lincoln Memorial?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well, we can go to see Mr. Lincoln. Or, we could watch on my television... (Reads from the screen) ‘Big Momma’s House’. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA (cont'd) It’s about a little black man who pretends to be a fat black lady. They showed a little bit and they’re all chasing after him - it looked hilarious Martin. She looks up at MARTIN, expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are two tiny figures gazing up at the great man.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Isn’t he wonderful. I’ve always wanted to see him in his big chair.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well he was big man. Literally. Six foot four. Tallest American president.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I can see that. He’s tall even sitting down. They both fall silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They set off down the steps. MARTIN is lining up a photo of PHILOMENA with Lincoln in background.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: «+. I had a friend and her daughter paid for her to go to Florida for her seventieth birthday and she said ‘Phil, the size of the portions - you wouldn’t believe’.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Stop there. I’m going to take your photograph. He gets out his camera. He fiddles with a setting.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Is this for the article?  61.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Erm, yeh.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Only I’m a little bit worried you see, because if I find him he might be very disapproving of talking to the papers. Families are very private things.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Half distracted, fiddling with camera) Well, yes, that’s true, but tracking him down’s a very expensive business so it’s a sort of quid pro quo...

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It means you don’t get something for nothing. He’s happy with the camera now and lines up the shot agai MARTIN (cont'd) I won't write anything you're unhappy with. Just the truth.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: That's the thing I’m worried about. A beat. She feels she has no option but to go along with PHILOMENA (cont’d) Should I smile or should I be serious?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Let’s do one happy, one not so happy, then we’re covered. (Poised to take it) Ready... PHILOMENA smiles, he takes the snap. She changes to a wor expression and he takes another snap. MARTIN (cont'd) Great.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LINCOLN MEMORIAL REFLECTING POOL/HOTDOG STAND. NIGHT
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA is working her way steadily through a huge hotd with onions and fries.  62.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: -if you want chips here, by the way Martin, you have to ask for French Fries. Because if you ask for chips they’1l just bring you crisps. (Thinks about this) And if you ask for crisps... well, I don’t know what they’1l bring you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Jet-lagged, just wanting to go to bed) Yes, it can be very confusing. PHILOMENA takes a thoughtful bite of her hotdog.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I’m getting scared... now we’re getting closer. (Beat) All these years, wondering whether Anthony was in trouble, or in prison... or goodness knows what. As long as I didn’t know, I could always tell myself that he was happy somewhere, and he was doing all right. She starts to get really upset. PHILOMENA (cont’d) But what if he died in Vietnam? Or came back with no legs, or lived on the street...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Gently) Well... no point upsetting yourself. We don’t know what we don’t know. We’ll just have to deal with that when we get there. She nods. Takes a slurp of her milk shake. They are further away, walking near some trees.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What if he was a drug addict Martin, or... what if he was obese?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Incredulous) Obese?  63.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I watched this documentary that said a lot of Americans are huge - what if that’s happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: But... what on earth makes you think he’d be obese?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Tearful) Well, because of the size of the portions... They walk away under the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN escorts PHILOMENA back to her room.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Night Philomena, if you need me just dial 7, and then my room number 524.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: 7524. Okay, good night Martin, and thank you. Oh - would you like some biscuits because they gave me two in a little packet and I don’t want them.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well if you change your mind just call me - what do you dial?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I dial 7534 for your room.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: If you need them just call 7534 and I‘1l bring them round to you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I won’t. But thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Good night Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Good night.  64. She closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Previously Sc. 69) NOW WE HAVE SOUND. Mid-80s. A track plays - ‘Doot Doot’ b Freur, as a POV shot, grainy early video, takes us throug packed ‘Studio 54’ type place, full of beautiful 80s peop lots of neon, flashing lights, wild hair styles, women wi bright lipstick and avant garde outfits. CLUBBERS part, smiling, as the camera ploughs between the whoever is shooting this wants to capture as many faces a memories of that night as possible. They react to the cam video cameras are a novelty. We hear snatches of conversation, high spirits. Finally the camera reaches a group of men and women in their 20s and 30s, including MA WELLER, late 20s, back-combed dark hair, bright lipstick. there in the middle of everyone is MICHAEL, now mid-30s, smiling, enigmatic. He speaks to the guy behind the camer

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hey Pete... MARCIA plants a kiss on MICHAEL’S cheek and gives the cam a smouldering look as they both ‘pose’ for the camera. Th scene tells us that Anthony/Michael has grown into a youn man with a louche, cool private life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The still image of a nun, wearing bright red lipstick, ey closed in ecstasy, her bare breasts covered by the hands another topless nun behind her wearing only a wimple. We REVEAL MARTIN has dozed off, fully clothed, on his bed, T remote on his stomach. The room phone rings, he wakes wit start and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hello? (Listens ) No... no I’ve got a bath robe Philomena. (Listens ) Yes, there are two in every room. And the slippers. (Listens) Thanks, see you in the morning. He hangs up, looks at the image of the nun, then checks h watch. Time to call home. He picks up his mobile and dial waits for a connection.  65. MARTIN (cont'd) Hello sweetheart, how’s everyone? He puts her onto speaker as he settles back onto the bed pours himself a miniature brandy over ice, takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We’re all good, Danny won his rugby match today and he nearly scored a try. How’s Philomena?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Big sigh) Well, I have now seen, first hand, what a lifetime’s diet of Reader’s Digest, the Daily Mail and romantic novels can do to a person’s brain. I don’t know who I want to strangle first - Mills or Boon. KATE laughs. MARTIN (cont'd) She keeps telling all the hotel staff how kind they are - she must think they’re volunteers. She met four people today who were all, ‘one in a million’. What are the chances of that?

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh come on she’s just a little old Irish lady. He finishes off his brandy.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Um... fleecy pyjamas, bed socks and men’s slippers.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Lying on the bed going through the movie menu.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Anything worth watching?  66.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: There’s one called ‘Naughty Habits’. ‘Forbidden pleasures of the flesh from behind convent walls’.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do they look like the nuns at Roscrea?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. I think these ones are a little more... charitable.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The still of the slutty nuns on screen.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PHILOMENA’S ROOM, WASHINGTON DC HOTEL - NIGHT PHILOMENA comes out of the bathroom in her full length nightie, kneels by the bed and says her prayers, then get bed and turns the light out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Previously Sc 66) 1982. Poor quality, taped VHS of news footage of a photo opportunity at the White House; President REAGAN is surrounded by ADVISORS. He turns to shake hands with the to his right; we see that it’s MICHAEL, smiling nervously undeniably thrilled to be amongst such illustrious compan We now see he is a man with what appears to be a stellar career in the making. But his appearance - conservative career-man - is totally at odds with the night-clubber we in scene 66. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARTIN’S ROOM, WASHINGTON DC HOTEL - NIGHT MARTIN has fallen asleep on his bed still fully clothed. Woken by his door buzzer, he rouses himself and answers i He looks through the spyhole and sees PHILOMENA outside i her dressing gown. He steels himself and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hello.  67.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Martin I wanted to tell you something earlier but it slipped my mind, and I was going to tell you on the phone but I forgot the number, so I thought I’d come and tell you in person what with you only being along the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What I wanted to say was, thank you Martin, for helping me to look for my son. I know you got the sack from your job - not News At Ten - the other one. And I just want to say, that their loss is my gain.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Stunned for a moment) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Good night Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Good night. She walks off. He shuts the door, not sure how to react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another of his morning constitutional jogs, to shake out jetlag. But there’s an unwelcome addition to the routine - other JOGGERS apparently much fitter than he. He chugs gamely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN is sitting at a table, working at his laptop, sipp from a black coffee. The breakfast area is busy, and in f of him PHILOMENA is enjoying herself investigating what i offer at the hot buffet. CLOSE UP: the computer screen. MARTIN is working through long list of files; we see pictures of different males of varying ages, all named ‘Anthony’ or ‘Tony’ Lee. Some Christian names are spelt with a ‘h’, some without; some surnames spelt ‘Leigh’ or ‘Lea’. Each file is different, have a military appearance, some civil, some even appear be criminal records.  68. MARTIN looks up and sees PHILOMENA chatting with the CHEF the omelette station and overhears a snatch of conversati

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: -we don’t really have Mexicans in England, we have the Indians instead, and everybody loves curry. He returns to his laptop. He is checking the photos attac to the records; one is a cutting showing a blonde busines shaking hands with somebody; another is a young black boy another is a man in a marines uniform. MARTIN dwells on s but quickly rejects others. He dials a number on his mobi waits impatiently for it to go through:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hi Caroline it’s Martin Sixsmith. Hi... (Listens ) Yes, I’m not getting any joy, but I just wanted to check - you know the file with the immigration cuttings? (Listens ) I know you’ve checked, but could you send me a link anyway? (Listens ) Thanks. He hangs up as PHILOMENA comes back over to the table, glancing briefly at the screen. MARTIN (cont'd) Morning.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Martin they’ve got pancakes over there, and waffles and omelettes - any filling - and cereals and bacon and sausage and-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yeh I know what’s over there.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: -anything you like. The breakfast is included isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes - I’m just not hungry. My stomach hasn’t woken up yet.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Mine wakes up before I do. I’m having a ham and Swiss cheese omelette - shall I get you one?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No thank you.  69.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Why don’t you have some blueberries?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Anything to stop the relentless barrage) Okay, yes. Great. Now a WAITRESS approaches their table.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Okay if you want to help yourself to breakfast over there we have a hot and cold buffet, fresh fruit and cereal, muffins, omelettes with a choice of-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I know-

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: -fillings.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: -I know exactly what is available for breakfast. So. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: (Trying to tempt him) We also have fresh pancakes?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Sharply) No. Thank you. I’m trying to have a private conversation here.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: My apologies sir. The WAITRESS leaves.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: There’s no need to be rude. He’s a very kind man, Antonio.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m sure he’s one in a million - well one in a hundred thousand.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  70.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You've said that to at least ten people now - so that’s just maths.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: You should be nice to people on the way up because you might meet them again on the way down. I’d have thought you of all people would understand that. This stings, though maybe she didn’t mean it to. And then again, maybe she did? PHILOMENA (cont’d) I’d rather you were rude to me than the nice people who work here.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m trying to help you find your son, that’s why we’re here. Okay? So, please- (Gestures to laptop) -just for now, can I have some quiet time? PHILOMENA looks at him, her nose defiantly up in the air. goes to say something but stops herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN is studying his laptop. He sees a new e-mail in hi inbox from ‘Owsianoska, Caroline’, entitled ‘Anthony Lee’ opens it and clicks on a link. As he waits for it to down he sees PHILOMENA back at the omelette station, and catch snippet of her renewed conversation with the CHEF.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: -were you born in Mexico? Well you must like nachos? My grand daughter Natalie got me into them. I’ve never been to Mexico - I hear it’s lovely apart from the kidnappings- Shaking his head in exasperation, he turns back to the sc where an image downloads line by line from the top of the screen. We make out a blurry newspaper photo of a little and girl, holding hands with a smart, middle-aged couple posing at an airport arrivals lounge. MARTIN hears PHILOM share a laugh with the CHEF and is about to look over to when the image reveals the boy is holding a tin toy aerop in his hand. Stunned, he recognizes it instantly. He has found Anthony. The headline above the cutting reads: ‘New Life For Irish Orphans’.  71. Excited, he scans the article, picks up the surname Hess finds the boy’s Christian name: Michael. He puts ‘Michael Hess, D.O.B. 07.05.52’ into a search eng waits a few moments, then clicks on a site - the official site of the Republican Party. There is a picture of the a Michael, early 30s, smiling, in a formal head and shoulde pose. But it’s the passage at the top of the page which j him: Michael A. Hess: (b) 07.05.52 - (d) 08.15.95. He sta at the legend (d). Surely not..? Scarcely able to believe it, he scans the article below t picture, picks out some key sentences: ‘Michael was broug to the US from Ireland by his adoptive parents...’ and th at the end: ’... Michael died on August 15th, 1995.’ See MARTIN: Oh God, he’s dead... MARTIN looks up to see PHILOMENA making her way back to t table with her omelette and a bowl of raspberries. In a p he quickly shuts down the window showing the young Anthon clutching the aeroplane. PHILOMENA (cont’d) They’ve run out of blueberries so I got you raspberries instead. MARTIN just stares at her, frozen expression. She misinterprets this as an admonishment. PHILOMENA (cont’d) Oh, I’m sorry. Quiet time. As PHILOMENA puts down her tray she glances at the screen now just displaying the image of the adult Michael in the formal pose. She stares at it and, even though she can’t what Anthony would look like as a grown man, puts her han her chest. PHILOMENA (cont’d) That’s my Anthony. She looks at MARTIN, who doesn’t answer. But his eyes not only confirm this they tell her something else... she clutches her crucifix. PHILOMENA (cont'd) He’s dead... isn’t he.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (A beat then he whispers, choked) Yes. (Beat) I’m sorry. A WAITRESS hovers holding a coffee pot.  72.

dialogues.speaker: WAIRTESS
dialogues.text: Coffee? There’s no answer; the WAITRESS hovers, obviously unaware what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Anguished) He doesn’t want coffee he wants blueberries! PHILOMENA starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (To the WAITRESS) Thank you, we don’t need anything. MARTIN tries to comfort PHILOMENA, putting his arms round awkwardly, self-consciously, speaking quietly to her. MARTIN (cont'd) I’m so sorry... She readily accepts the comfort. SCORE: Music by BACH...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACH CONTINUES over... We see PHILOMENA in the back of a taxi on the way to the airport, the lights of the city playing on her window. Sh numb, disengaged from all that’s going on around her. The taxi stops at some traffic lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACH CONTINUES, building to a swell... PHILOMENA stares out at the PEOPLE in the street; she can understand how life is going on when Anthony is gone. She sees a YOUNG WOMAN picked up by her BOYFRIEND and swung r playfully as he gives her a kiss. He then pretends liftin her has hurt his back; she laughs. MARTIN looks across to PHILOMENA, not knowing what to say The lights change, the taxi pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA sits by herself on a row of chairs in the airpo lounge, this ‘cathedral’ to modern life. We see her in profile, staring inscrutably at something. She seems sudd old, bird like. Now we REVEAL what she’s looking at: a pi of iconography - a huge Calvin Klein poster in portrait aspect of a beautiful female model laughing in a casual embrace with a devastatingly handsome, be-stubbled male model. She wears a negligee, he wears a vest. They have perfect teeth. Perfect lives. They are shamelessly happy. SCORE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA sits with MA SALLY (CONT'D) (cont'd) What did he die of?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know, I didn’t find out. We're at the airport now.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (Interrupts him) Wait - you’re at the airport?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yeh. Obviously she wants to get back home, be with her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What about the story?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Confused) Well... he’s dead. SALLY shakes her head curtly at the SUB EDITOR - she does like his layout.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Dead or alive, happy or sad - you said it - they’re both good. Spin it, find a story..

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yeh, but if I stay here and she goes, no-one’s going to answer my questions.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Then keep her there.  74.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What? Come on... she’s in bits. It’s like she’s lost him all over again.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That’s great - write that line down.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yes, you signed a contract. Call me when you've got something. She hangs up. MARTIN looks at PHILOMENA, sitting quietly, looking up at the poster. He feels a wave of terrible gui

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: MARTIN sits down next to PHILOMENA. A few moment’s silenc they both look up at the poster together; PHILOMENA stare the female model, laughing, carefree.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I remember that day at the fair, his father made me laugh by pretending to be an old man. (Smiles, remembering) And then I made him laugh by pretending to be an old lady. (Beat, the smile disappears) And now I am one... I’1l never know if Anthony ever thought about me. I’‘1l never be able to say sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Beat, not quite sure how to put it) Look, we don’t have to... (Voice tails off) We can... stay.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Stay?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If you want to?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What for? And now he must grit his teeth and begin the lie.  75.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I was thinking we could... maybe talk to some people who knew him, find out what happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I think I’d rather just go home. On Martin: so this is what it has come down to - forced t persuade an old lady to stay with him against her wishes, against his better judgement.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I... think it might help, in terms of your loss. She looks at him, unable to speak for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Will it?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: There’s lot of research which suggests that... people who’ve suffered a loss can help... overcome it by talking to people who knew the person that died and, from them, learning about his life, sort of thing... A halting, inarticulate and wholly unconvincing attempt. didn’t even come close to convincing himself.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes it’s quite well known... I really think it could help. She nods, not really in any state to argue, and allows hi help her up. We can see from his face how shitty he feels

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: SCENE DELETED (Now Sc. 78A)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1988. MICHAEL and MARCIA are being walked by a REALTOR towards a house for sale;  76. PETE is behind the camera videoing them - we think they m very well be a young couple looking at a home to start a family in. The house itself is a sprawling, typically New England property set in large grounds.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: It’s incredible... (Beat) What about you? She takes the camera from him, turns it on PETE.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeh, pretty cool. (Nods to MICHAEL) What about the lord of the manor? She now turns the camera on to MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’ve fallen in love already...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN and PHILOMENA walk back up to the reception desk w their shoulder bags. The RECEPTIONIST recognizes them:

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Hello, you're back again?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes... (Little bit embarrassed) ... change of plan.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (Checking display on her screen) We have the same rooms if you’d like them?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Um... okay. The RECEPTIONIST starts to enter information on her compu An awkward beat whilst she taps away at her keyboard.  77.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I suppose they’1ll just have to use the ‘not so happy’ photo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are back in Philomena’s old room. MARTIN is at a des tapping away at his laptop, PHILOMENA is sitting on a sof watching ‘Big Momma’s House’. MARTIN, uncomfortable with heavy emotion of the situation, looks across to her, sees has a glazed expression:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I thought it would make me laugh. MARTIN tries to make some sense of what she’s watching.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Is that a man?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’ve been sent a picture of Anthony - do you want to see it?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh... (She thinks about this) Yes please. He offers her his chair; she gets up and walks over, sitt down in front of his laptop. She puts her glasses on and stares at the photo: it’s a wide, group shot with about twenty people in it, including Anthony and Marcia, at a formal function.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It's from a woman we’re meeting tomorrow called Marcia Weller, she was a colleague of Anthony’s... now shall we have a drink? He bends down by the mini-bar.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: He looks very smart.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He worked in the legal department for the American government. Brandy isn’t it... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN (cont'd) (Searching through mini- bar) Oh, they’re all gone.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Yes I had them earlier.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Getting up) Never mind, I’1l get you one from my room. He walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Martin... This man looks just like you. He stops by the door. She points to a figure in the back of the photo. MARTIN walks back over to the desk and look more closely. Puzzled, he enlarges the picture slightly, looks intently at the figure.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Long beat) It is me. Sure enough, it’s him, in profile, talking to someone; Michael is standing just a few feet away from him. Mind spinning as he studies the photo, fragments of memory com back to MARTIN. That name - he knew he’d heard it before. MARTIN (cont'd) Michael Hess... I met him.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: At the White House.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh dear God...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It was when I was with the BBC. (Searching his memory) Would have been about... ten years ago.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Hungrily) What was he like?  79. Now we see the first chink in Martin’s armour of detachme he is personally involved. He knows how desperate PHILOME is for information, and he wants to help - but he can’t. stares again at the grainy, blown up image of him standin just a few feet away from Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Erm... I can’t remember too much... (Grasping at straws) It was a Republican thing... (Racking his brain) I don’t really remember.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: You must remember something.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Suddenly something comes to him) I shook hands with him, he was by the door as we entered.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What was his handshake like? MARTIN looks at her, not even remembering this but desper to come up with something for her.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well, if it had been a weak handshake I'd have remembered it. No-one would get to that position with a weak handshake.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: So he had a strong handshake?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well that’s something. (Beat) What else?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Erm... he looked very smart.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh I always dressed him smart. Can you remember anything he said?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I... can’t. (Thinks really hard) Just... ‘hello’ or something. I’m sorry.  80.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Repeating the word, as if it were significant) ‘Hello.’

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Might have been ‘Hi’. By an effort of will she puts her disappointment behind h

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter... As she always does, PHILOMENA concentrates on the positiv PHILOMENA (cont'd) (Big smile) He was smart, and he had a firm handshake. She tries to convince herself that if this is all she fin out about him, it will be enough. MARTIN is uncomfortable with himself. SCORE: PIANO MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: SCORE CONTINUES OVER
dialogues.text: In the background the CAPITOL. PHILOMENA looks a little bewildered as she goes up the steps with MARTIN. SCORE DIPS and we HEAR FROM INSIDE:

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Philomena, I’m Marcia Weller. Welcome to Washington...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA is confronted with a table covered with photos Michael, stunned at this feast laid out for her - a feast memories she never had. There are a mix of formal and cas photos. We see some of him with Marcia on his arm dressed formally in evening wear.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: I knew your son for about ten years. He was senior legal counsel to both the Reagan and Bush administrations.  81. MARCIA WELLER, (the woman in the flashback video), is now years older, a successful lawyer in her own right. PHILOM picks up a photograph of Michael with President Reagan at function we saw in flashback earlier.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (To PHILOMENA) Didn't do too badly, did he? PHILOMENA studies the picture.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: He’d never have got a job like that if he’d stayed with me. (Staring at the photo, her mind begins to drift) I think he would have worked at McEverleys. She looks up, sees MARTIN’S and MARCIA’S blank faces. PHILOMENA (cont’d) They're a firm of solicitors in Castlebar. Did he ever mention Ireland to you Marcia?

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: I don’t think so - not that I remember. But I have a number for his sister, Mary, who came from Ireland with him - I can put you in touch with her?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, excellent. That’s good news. PHILOMENA picks up a photo of Michael in a garden, leanin against some hay bales wearing a T-shirt and dungarees.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: He looks very happy here, who’s this fella? She picks up a picture of Pete Olsson, tall, handsome, bearded.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: That’s his, er, friend - Pete. She puts that photo down and picks up another of Michael Marcia on a night out together.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Were you his girlfriend Marcia?

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: Oh no. I loved Michael but not in that way... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARCIA (cont'd) (Looks at MARTIN, awkward) «+. I don’t know if you knew, but he was gay. MARTIN seems to freeze at this news; PHILOMENA appears no react at all. MARCIA (cont'd) I would accompany him when he went to official functions because being gay was frowned upon in the Republican party. But he was very charming and very charismatic. PHILOMENA clasps her chest.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I knew it Martin... I knew he'd be charismatic. (To MARCIA) Now did he father any children Marcia?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She just told us that Anthony was gay.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh, I always knew that. I just thought he might have been bi- curious. (They look at her) A lot of the nurses I worked with were gay but one of them, called Brendan, told me he was bi-curious. I don’t think he could make up his mind Marcia.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: He didn’t have any children. I’m sorry. PHILOMENA gives her a smile and a little nod then returns the pictures. She picks up a different photo of Michael i Pete’s arms, both smiling, looking happy.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Did Pete love him?

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: Yes he did. OUT on the photo of Michael and Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA and MARTIN walk down steps, away from the Capit building.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How did you know he was gay? (She looks at him) You said in there you already knew. .?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well, he was a very sensitive little soul. And as the years rolled on I always wondered if he might be. Then, when I saw that photograph of him in the dungarees, well there was no doubt in my mind...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE US- DAY
dialogues.text: A middle of the range Chevrolet hire car passes the husks a cornfield in a rural part of the US.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHEVROLET, ANOTHER PART OF THE US
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA watches the flat countryside speeding by her wi as MARTIN drives.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHEVROLET, ANOTHER PART OF THE US
dialogues.text: The car turns into the drive of a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens to REVEAL MARY, early 50s, a plain, tired-looking housewife with long, greying hair. SCORE ENDS.  84.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mary?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. PHILOMENA and MARTIN stand on the doorstep; PHILOMENA una to prevent herself from staring at MARY.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This is Philomena. Anthony's mother. (Corrects himself) Michael’s mother.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Um... okay.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Long beat, looking at

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You look just like your mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY, PHILOMENA and MARTIN sit at a table in the garden, PHILOMENA looking through a wallet of photos Mary has giv her. Mary’s two grandchildren, a BOY aged 5 and a girl, 3 play together. PHILOMENA studies a photo of Michael with elderly woman with glasses and grey hair, (MARGE).

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That’s our mother - I mean, our adopted mother.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Was she a nice lady Mary - she looks like a nice lady.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (Beat) I won’t lie to you Philomena, we didn’t have the happiest childhood. (Beat) Marge was okay but our father, Doc, could be a very hard man. PHILOMENA falls quiet for a few moments. MARY sees the KI are trying to climb onto a shed. MARY (cont'd) Hey get down off there!

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Sorry grandma.  85. PHILOMENA now turns to a picture of Michael with Pete’s a around him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That’s him with Pete Olsson. He and Mike were... She falters, not sure if they know about Michael’s sexual She turns

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: It’s all right Mary, I know that Anthony was a gay homosexual. And we met Marcia - who I believe was his beard, is that right Martin?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Stumbly ) Erm... yes, I think that’s about right. to another picture of Michael, looking thin and ill, and digests what it means.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: It must have been terrible, having to keep it a secret his whole life. She’s talking about Anthony but we know she is also talki about herself.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA (cont'd) (Beat, quiet voice) I assume my son died from Aids.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. He did. He wasn’t too happy with himself, last couple of years of his life... working for the Republicans.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: The irony wasn’t lost on him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. He was pretty mixed up about it. looks up, puzzled, from studying a photo.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Explaining to PHILOMENA) The Republicans cut funding into Aids research because they blamed the epidemic on gay lifestyles.  86.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Suddenly understanding) Ahhh - because some of them wouldn’t wear condoms because they said it spoilt the feeling. See MARTIN and MARY, looking uncomfortable. PHILOMENA (cont'd) Where’s he buried Mary?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You know, I think it’s out in West Virginia near where he lived. Dad wanted him buried in the family plot in St. Louis but Pete wouldn't allow it. They had a big row - I didn’t go in the end, I didn’t want to get involved. You should talk to Pete about it. A silence. The unfolding soap opera of Anthony's life see alien to PHILOMENA. She feels disconnected, unable to rel to it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Stepping in) We got his number from Marcia - we'll go and see him, won't we Philomena.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Hmm... PHILOMENA clutches at one last straw. PHILOMENA (cont'd) Mary, can I just ask, there’s one thing I’d like to know. Did Anthony ever mention Ireland, or where he'd come from?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (She thinks, then shrugs) Not really. Neither of us really talked about that.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No. Why would you... She smiles weakly, but is crushed. We move slowly to a CL UP on PHILOMENA as the SCORE swells, MARTIN’S small talk like white noise in the background...  87.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Well thank you for seeing us, we should probably get going - got a long drive in front of us. Thank you for your time... «+. until we are alone with PHILOMENA and her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. POTOMAC VILLAGE HOUSE
dialogues.text: 1993. The start of a momentous journey for MICHAEL. A han held shot in the hallway, he descends the last few stairs carrying a case. He looks frail and ill. From behind the camera:

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Okay, forty five minutes late, but here he is at last. Ready for his big adventure.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Turn that off Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Don’t be such a grouse. PETE turns the camera on himself. PETE (cont'd) He’s such a grouse. Turns the camera back on MICHAEL. PETE (OOV) (cont’d) Why are you wearing that top - it’s too big for you.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: All my clothes are too big for me. MICHAEL walks past the camera and opens t he door. Outsid see a taxi waiting on the drive. MICHAEL shuffles towards

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHEVROLET, RURAL US
dialogues.text: MARTIN drives them back towards the city through the same featureless landscape of trees and farmland. They travel silence, PHILOMENA turning everything over in her mind. MARTIN is distracted by the St. Christopher Philomena has again hung from the vent, gently knocking against the das Finally, she turns to him:  88.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I was going to ask you Martin, if it would be possible to not use my real name when you write the story? He looks at her, doesn’t answer. PHILOMENA (cont’d) Perhaps you could call me Nancy? I’ve always loved that name. My niece is called Nancy... oh - people might think it’s her. (Thinks some more) What about Helen? Helen Keller? No, there’s someone already called that, isn’t there.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m going to have to call you by your real name, Philomena. That’s the way it works. I’m sorry. She thinks about this for a few moments, then goes back t looking out of the window. A long beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I'd like to stop off and go to confession, if we could find a church on the way back.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Beat) If you don’t mind me asking, why do you feel the need to go to confession? (She doesn’t answer) It’s the Catholic Church should go to confession. (Beat) Imagine that, the confession box would explode.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: In the greatest saint there is a speck of dust, in the greatest sinner, a spark of gold.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: You learn that in the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes and it’s an interesting book but there are other better books.  89.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know... He was going to drop it, but he starts to think of some titles. MARTIN (cont'd) Anna Karenina, 1984, Great Expectations... (Beat) I think if everyone who’s read the bible had read something else instead, the world would be a better place. PHILOMENA sniffs, contemptuously. MARTIN (cont'd) And I mean literally anything - the Slipper and the Horseshoe even.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well you’re being silly now - they’re both good books. He sighs exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. REMOTE CATHOLIC CHURCH, RURAL US
dialogues.text: The Chevrolet pulls up outside a little Catholic church; whitewashed clapboard exterior.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Read a very funny headline in a satirical newspaper the other day, about the Asian Tsunami.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHEVROLET, REMOTE CATHOLIC CHURCH, RURAL US
dialogues.text: MARTIN turns to PHILOMENA as she prepares to get out.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It said: ‘God outdoes terrorists yet again’. Found that very amusing... Why God feels the need to occasionally wipe out hundreds of thousands of innocent people escapes me. PHILOMENA opens her door.  90. MARTIN (cont'd) Why don’t you ask Him about that while you’re in there. Probably just say He moves in mysterious ways. PHILOMENA turns back to him; he wears a smiling, supercil expression.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No, I think He’1ll just say that you're a feckin’ eejit. His expression freezes - stunned at her using language li this. She exits the car, slamming the door behind her. MA watches her go inside, feeling completely discombobulated

dialogues.speaker: INT. RURAL CATHOLIC CHURCH, RURAL US
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA enters the church and looks around. A handful o PARISHIONERS are dotted about the pews or queueing to go the two confessional boxes. Dark, wooden panelling and pe dominate the ornate interior. She sits down quietly by on the boxes - small lights above them telling her they are in use - to wait.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (From incoming scene) Hi Sally...

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What have you got for me?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RURAL CATHOLIC CHURCH, RURAL US
dialogues.text: MARTIN paces about by the car as he speaks on his mobile.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Okay, well he was a bigshot lawyer in the Reagan and Bush administrations-—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALLY is at her desk, half distracted by an e-mail she wa composing. [INTERCUT between both scenes]

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You're kidding - that’s amazing!  91.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And at the same time he was a closet homosexual who died of Aids.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Wow. MARTIN now has her full attention. She abandons her e-mai and swings her chair to face the window. SALLY (cont'd) This is perfect for the weekend section.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, and I met him.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You met him? So there’s a personal angle?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well... yeh, that’s... one of the angles. Definitely. (Trying to convince himself) But the thing is, people need to know what happened here - it’s an injustice.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What about the evil nuns? What’s happening with them?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh still there, they haven't gone away. If anything they’re actually a bit more evil.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You know, I think this could even be a cover piece.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Suddenly chuffed) Really?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It’s great Martin, it presses so many buttons... She continues. Though excited by her praise, his eyes wan over to the church, and to the little cross above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. RURAL CATHOLIC CHURCH, RURAL US —- DAY MARTIN enters quietly and stands at the back in the lobby area, looking about, taking in the quiet ambience. MARTIN sees a Crucifix on the wall, blood pouring from a wound t Christ's side. He turns to see a YOUNG WOMAN, a country g dressed simply, stand in front of the altar and genuflect She walks down the aisle, dips her fingers in the holy wa bowl near the exit, and blesses herself. As she passes MA on her way out she gives him a warm smile of open friends which he feels compelled to return. The exchange unsettle him; she has a grace which is at odds with his notion of bullying church. He returns his gaze to the confession bo a light is on over one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA is kneeling in the darkened cubicle. From behin the curtain we hear a voice:

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Hello. She can’t respond. She has no idea what she wants to say. PRIEST (OOV) (cont'd) Hello? Speak up now, don’t be afraid. She starts to cry, silently, bitterly, tears streaming do her cheeks. Finally, from the other side of the grille: PRIEST (OOV) (cont’d) Have faith. God will forgive you... PHILOMENA gets up, she can take no more. Quickly dabbing eyes, she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RURAL CATHOLIC CHURCH RURAL US
dialogues.text: On MARTIN: footsteps and he turns to see PHILOMENA walkin towards him, set expression. Still dabbing her eyes, she walks down the aisle and exits the church without acknowledging him or blessing herself - as the young woma did. A beat on MARTIN. He looks at the holy water in the bowl, and dips his fingers in it. He looks at it glisteni on his skin. Why did Philomena not bless herself? He wipe his fingers on his trousers and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. REMOTE CATHOLIC CHURCH, RURAL US
dialogues.text: Worried that she’s having some sort of crisis/breakdown, MARTIN catches up with PHILOMENA as she heads for the car

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Look, you were right, I was being a ‘feckin’ eejit’ before, okay? And I’m sorry... She reaches the car; turns to face him across the roof affecting a faux formality:

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I was doing some thinking in there. I’m going to get a loan from the Bradford and Bigley Martin-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Bingley.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: -because I don’t have a mortgage now and I can have an extension for ten thousand pounds - my friend Rene did that and had a conservatory built. I don’t need a conservatory and I could give you the money to cover the cost of all the flights and the hotel rooms and then you won’t be out of pocket and you won’t have to publish the story because I don’t want it published - I don’t want anyone to know about this, ever. She is a keeping a tight rein on her emotions.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You haven’t done anything wrong. You are entitled to find out who your son was.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well, you heard what Mary said - she said he never gave me a second thought. He wasn’t my Anthony - he was somebody else’s Michael. He probably hated the thought of me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You don’t know that Philomena.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I should never have let him out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: We need to talk to Pete Olssen. He lived with him. He knew him better than anyone. Martin’s phone rings. He checks the display: ‘Sally Mitchell’. He holds his finger up apologetically to PHILO and answers:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hi - sorry can I call you back.... Yep, I’1l call you back. Okay. (Hangs up, back to

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: People need to know about what happened to you. This is an injustice, it needs to be exposed. She looks into his eyes, senses that his priorities are n longer what she thought they were. Her voice lowers.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: You’d better call your friend back... She gets in the car. OUT on MARTIN, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1993. The next leg of Michael’s journey. The camera is on MICHAEL, trying to doze, looking really ill. He sees Pete filming him.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Trying to smile) Oh... not too chipper.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Excited?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I guess. (Beat) Hopeful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN and PHILOMENA walk up to their hotel rooms in sile She gets to hers first, but can’t work the key-card. He inserts his and opens his door straight away. He looks ac to her struggling.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You need to put it in with the arrows pointing down.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Coldly - she’s still angry with him) I know how to do it. She takes the key-card out, turns it round, re-inserts it opens the door. She goes inside, the door clicking behind her. A moment on MARTIN, aware of the disconnect with PHILOMENA, before he enters his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having missed a few days, MARTIN is on another jog. He sp on his mobile as he runs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hello yes, I’m trying to set up a meeting with Peter Olsson... (Listens ) Yes I’ve called a couple of times but no-one’s returned my calls. I’m not quite sure what the next step is... I feel like I’m hitting a bit of a brick wall... (Listens ) Okay but if I could get a personal number- They’ve hung up on him. He ends the call, frustrated. An athletic-looking black GUY passes him running backwards.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: You should try it like this... it’s easier this way! MARTIN ‘laughs’, ‘good-naturedly’. He slows to a walk, fe with keeping fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweaty and exhausted, MARTIN knocks on the door to the ro He waits. No answer.  96.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Phil? He puts his ear to the door. Nothing. MARTIN (cont'd) Philomena? I’ve left my laptop in your room... He knocks again. Nothing. Not a sound. He looks concerned

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN is back down in reception with the RECEPTIONIST, w is calling up to the room.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (Hangs up) No answer.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Perplexed) Erm... she wouldn’t have gone anywhere by herself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN and the BELLBOY walk along the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: .-. it might be nothing but she is quite old and... Irish. (Berates himself) I shouldn’t have left her on her own...

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: And she’s a relative? ‘Cos I can’t let you in unless she’s a relative.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, she’s a relative.

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: What relative is she?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She's... my mother.

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: Okay...  97. They are by the door, the BELLBOY inserts his pass key.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PHILOMENA’S ROOM, WASHINGTON DC HOTEL - NIGHT The BELLBOY and MARTIN enter.

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: (Calling out as he enters) Concierge! Seeing the room is empty MARTIN quickly heads for bathroo door - knocking and then pushing it open. It’s empty.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Phil? (Realising the BELLBOY is watching him) Mum? MARTIN comes back out into the room now starting to panic MARTIN (cont'd) She’s gone...

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: Try the balcony. MARTIN slides the door back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN steps out onto the balcony - and there is PHILOMEN standing gripping a hand rail, looking out at the city ni scape, eyes red and tear-stained.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: There you are!

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I wondered where you were.

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: (From inside) Is your mother okay now?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: (From inside) Okay sir.  98. MARTIN shoots an embarrassed glance to PHILOMENA as the BELLBOY leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I... had to say that to get him to let me in. (Embarrassed, quickly changing the subject) You shouldn’t have the balcony door shut if you can’t hear the door to the room.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I was just out here having a little cry, that’s all. She is quite calm - if anyone is distressed it’s MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Right. He nods his head, an awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I hope you didn’t think I was going to jump off the balcony? A little smile plays across her lips as it occurs to her he might well have been thinking this.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No of course not. Can I, er... get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No thank you. I just want to have... (Phrase pops into her head) -some quiet time.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. Right, well I’1l see you later. MARTIN turns and leaves, duly dismissed and suddenly feel redundant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN is at the bar, changed and showered, laptop in fro of him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Pint of Guinness please.  99. As the BARMAN pours him one, MARTIN turns things over in mind.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: MARTIN sits at his laptop, but he’s distracted, can’t concentrate. He studies the pint of Guinness in front of He takes a sip, puts the glass down. As he studies it, absentmindedly running his finger down the side of it, something catches his eye: the trademark Guinness Celtic symbol on the side of the glass. He stares at it, thought Remembering something. Suddenly, it all clicks into place but before he can do anything:

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Martin, there’s something I have to say to you- He looks up, surprised to see her down in the bar. PHILOMENA (cont'd) I’ve made a decision and my mind’s made up and there’s nothing you can say that’s going to make me change it. (Beat) I appreciate everything you’ve done for me, and thank you for putting up with me, I’ve enjoyed the hotels and all the food and everything, but this hasn't really worked out the way that I wanted it to. So, tomorrow I think we should get on an aeroplane and go back to England. There it is, and that’s an end to it. (Beat) And don’t try to change my mind by saying all clever things and trying to confuse me because I didn’t go to Oxbridge like you- MARTIN’S mobile starts to ring, interrupting the argument checks the display: ‘Sally Mitchell’ and quickly kills th call without answering. He looks at her:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oxford. I went to Oxford - Oxbridge is a portmanteau of Oxford and Cambridge, that’s where two words-

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I don’t give a shiny shoe about that - it’s all the same to me! MARTIN begins to fiddle with his lap-top.  100.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I think we should go and visit Pete Olsson tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Go on your own! I’m not going all that way just to hear another person say that Anthony didn’t give two hoots about me, and that I abandoned him and all the rest of it... MARTIN points to the Harp symbol on the side of his pint Guinness.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: All I want to do is go home and mind my own business, and watch David Attenborough on the telly and I’'1l be happy with that.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: There. On the side of the glass. What’s that? He points more deliberately to the symbol.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: It’s a Celtic harp.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Right... He has found what he was looking for in his computer (tho we don’t yet see what he’s looking at). He now turns the computer round to show her the picture of Anthony with President Reagan, which we’ve seen before. He zooms in on Anthony so it’s just him in the frame, and we can see tha his jacket lapel he is wearing a gold Celtic Harp badge. MARTIN (cont'd) And what’s that?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Beat) A Celtic Harp.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If he cared so little about where he came from, why would he wear something so Irish? She thinks about it all, slightly stunned at the implications.  101.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Perhaps he played the harp? He was gay..?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He didn’t play the harp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1993. Now nearing journey’s end. We see the ruins of an Abbey. The camera pans to MICHAEL standing beside a hire Leaning on a stick, clearly ill, gazing at the ruins and over to a loch; before him rolling hills and fields, a th mist hanging in the air. [NOTE: we do not yet know where is]. He then brings the camera round onto a shot of MICHA gazing out at it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: What do you think? MICHAEL flicks a look across at the camera then returns t the view, taking comfort from it in spite of how ill he looks.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s pretty amazing. So peaceful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC OVER: a MONTAGE SEQUENCE showing the little hire ca making the pilgrimage into the suburbs of Washington to Michael’s former home in Potomac Village. They drive unde large manicured trees into a manicured village. We take i the ever changing landscape; we see miscellaneous shots o people and resonant landmarks along the route. We see PHILOMENA through her open window, alongside MARTIN, driv She is slurping on some monstrous creamy, syrupy Frappucc concoction, enjoying the wind on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT: late afternoon, Michael’s house in Potomac Village, which we saw earlier in a flash of video. The hi car is parked under some trees overlooking the house. MUSIC ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hire car pulls into the drive, as far from the house possible. PHILOMENA and MARTIN study the house.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I think he would have been happy living in a house like that, don’t you Martin?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t complain.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Beat) I couldn't have given him a life like this. She gazes at the house, delighting on every detail. PHILOMENA (cont’d) (Nervous ) So what do we do now? The car pulls forward. MARTIN surveys the empty drive.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: We doorstep him.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What’s that, doorstep?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s what nasty journalists do when they want to speak to somebody who doesn’t want to speak to them. She nods, thoughtfully, then sees something in the mirror

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh look Martin - a little red Mazda. A red, open top Mazda Miata passes and turns into the dri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mazda pulls up in front of the house. MARTIN reverses hire car into a place where he can see the Mazda without being seen. A man in his late 40s, (it’s PETE - he’s olde but we recognize him from the snatches of home video we’v seen him in), gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windscreen they watch as PETE leans across an kisses goodbye a younger MAN who is driving. We see PHILO silently watching. MARTIN checks PETE against a picture h holds up of MICHAEL and PETE.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That’s him - that’s Pete Olssen.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Martin, whatever he thinks... I did love my son.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: We don’t know what he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (beat) We what do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: We doorstep him.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s that nasty journalists do when they want to speak to somebody who doesn’t want to speak to them. PETE disappears inside the house and the Mazda drives off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment later, the hire car pulls up nearer the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN goes to get out of the car

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This shouldn’t take long...

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Suddenly panicking) But he won’t want to speak to me - he’1l just shut the door in your face. He gives her a confident smile and gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow MARTIN as he walks up to the front door and rin the bell without hesitation. A few moments, then PETE ans it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hello Peter Olssen?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m Martin Sixsmith, I’m here with Philomena Lee, the mother of your late partner Michael Hess... Sure enough, PETE’S immediate reaction is to shut the doo him, but MARTIN jams his foot in it. He and PETE make eye contact. So far so good. MARTIN (cont'd) Can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: If you move your foot. MARTIN moves his foot - and PETE immediately slams the do shut in his face. MARTIN has been completely outwitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA in the car. She sees MARTIN turn away and walk back, defeated. Her heart goes out to him, but she can fe the anger rising in her. MARTIN gets in the car, utterly deflated. A few moment’s silence:  105.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (With a lot of feeling) I’ve not been very... helpful, have I.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Never mind, at least you tried. A moment, then PHILOMENA gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Startled) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Wait here. The door was slammed in Martin’s face - but it was slamme her face too. She marches off to have this out with Pete, once and for all. MARTIN reluctantly stays in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now follow PHILOMENA up to the door. She rings the bel and again PETE answers. Expecting MARTIN again, he looks PHILOMENA, thrown by the sight of this little old lady no his doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I just want to talk about my son. He was taken from me. And I’ve been looking for him ever since. OUT on PETE, totally unprepared for this. But as he looks her, he sees the honesty shining through. And we know he not going to shut the door on her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP on a plasma screen. SCORE OVER the SUPER 8 foota we saw earlier of little Anthony on the airport tarmac, clutching his aeroplane and wearing his smart coat. The footage moves into a CLOSE UP of little ANTHONY. Over thi image we now see PHILOMENA’S face appear, translucently, that of her son.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: PHILOMENA, flickering blue light playing across her glass as she watches the footage on the screen, tears in her ey PETE sits next to her, holding her hand. MARTIN stands be her, also watching.  106. SCORE CONTINUES as PHILOMENA catches up on the moments fr Anthony’s/Michael’s life we have seen previously, (the li boy on the tarmac; the birthday party; with Ronald Reagan the club in New York; with Pete etc.) The two stories we have been watching now finally collide and we CUT BACK AND FORTH between PHILOMENA’S face and th screen, each time tightening in on her. We see the ruined Abbey amongst the images. Eventually we abandon the scree and stay with PHILOMENA, closing in ever tighter as she witnesses a life compacted, catching up on fifty missed y with these magical, ghostly images. Finally, she turns to MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Isn’t he handsome Martin? We are ON MARTIN, him watching the screen (which we don’t see). He does not respond to Philomena, his eyes transfix by something he is looking at. Seeing his expression she TURNS BACK, puzzled, to look at the screen - and her expression pales. PHILOMENA (cont'd) No...

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? And NOW we CUT TO the plasma screen and see MICHAEL... outside Roscrea. He is being greeted warmly by the (now elderly) Sister HILDEGARDE [NOTE - SISTER CLAIRE IS NOT I THE SHOT]. And this is the end of the journey started in scene 89 - Michael’s journey back to Roscrea. Suggest the insertion of a line at the following point, t draw out Philomena’s reaction to Anthony coming back to Roscrea:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He went to Ireland? He went to Roscrea...?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I took him. He was looking for you, Philomena.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (looking at the screen) He came to look for me?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Pointing to HILDEGARDE) That nun... I saw her at Roscrea on our last trip.  107.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Sister Hildegard.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She's very old now but it was definitely her.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: They always told me they didn’t know where Anthony was. PETE looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But they told us that they couldn’t find you. They said you’d abandoned him as a baby.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Whisper, voice full of emotion) I did not abandon my child. MARTIN gets up, unable to contain his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She was looking for him! She's spent her whole life trying to find him.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: He’s there now.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I had this huge standoff with his father. He wanted him buried in the US, but it was your son’s dying wish. He said he wanted to go home. Beat. Silence. PETE (cont'd) He’s buried at Roscrea. During this we have been moving slowly in on PHILOMENA’S face; now she closes her eyes, clutches her hand to her c and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are driving up the drive to the Abbey. The shots are t same as they were in the earlier scene.  108. MARTIN drives, PHILOMENA alongside. As they pull up outsi the Abbey they fall quiet for a moment, pondering what’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: We’ve come full circle.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: ‘The end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started, and know the place for the first time’.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh Martin that’s lovely, did you just think of that?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, it’s TS Eliot.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Well never mind it’s still nice.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Shall we go in?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (beat) You’re not going to make a scene in there are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m just going to ask a few questions. (As he gets out, anger rising) And I don’t want any tea, and I don’t want any cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk up to the Abbey building together in silence, PHILOMENA’S expression set, her emotions only just in che MARTIN looks angry. At the Abbey building PHILOMENA press the buzzer and, as before, the YOUNG NUN opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: Ah, do come in Philomena. PHILOMENA and MARTIN enter.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MEETING ROOM, ROSCREA —- DAY The YOUNG NUN leads them into the room.  109.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: Sister Claire has asked if you could wait here for her. MARTIN gives PHILOMENA a thunderous look ‘after all that’ happened they still want to make you wait?’ But as the YO NUN leaves the room and they sit down in chairs facing th window, PHILOMENA leans in and speaks quietly to him:

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Now remember Martin, it’s not her fault. She didn’t know that Anthony had a different name. Of course she is saying this as much to herself as Martin Frustrated, he leans back in his chair in angry silence, up, paces about. He stops to look at a classic ‘Sacred He image of Jesus on the wall, one so familiar to Irish households: Christ, palms turned outwards, displays stigm wounds, and his heart is visible beneath his robes, glowi and enveloped in a crown of thorns. He turns to see PHILO sitting on the edge of her chair, bag on her lap, waiting obediently that he is irritated by her. He looks at his w - the delay in seeing them is outrageous. He can’t stand in this room any more and slips quietly outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He emerges by the gift stand, checks that there is no-one around, then - his blood up - crosses to the double doors through which he saw Sister HILDEGARDE on his last visit. knows through there is where the nuns live. He slips quie through the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN propels himself along, trying the first couple of doors - they are all locked. He carries on and tries anot door - and this one is open. He slips inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small kitchen area. It’s empty, but an electric kettle boils on the side - someone was here very recently. Anoth door on the far side of the kitchen: he strides over to i opens it and enters another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters a communal living area. Two elderly NUNS are in there; they turn to face him - neither is HILDEGARDE. The from a door to his left, SISTER CLAIRE and a PRIEST emerg As they shut the door behind them he sees, in the room be them, in a wheelchair, Sister HILDEGARDE. This is who he looking for.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Excuse me what do you think you're doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I just want to ask Sister Hildegarde something. The YOUNG NUN enters the TV room behind him, breathless, having followed him.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NUN
dialogues.text: (To SISTER CLAIRE) He just walked straight in. They are momentarily distracted by her, and MARTIN uses t to slip past them and reach HILDEGARDE’s door.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: This is completely inappropriate behaviour! MARTIN ignores him and enters the room, shutting the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HILDEGARDE’S ROOM, ROSCREA - DAY MARTIN sees there is a key in the door which he turns, locking himself in. He turns to face HILDEGARDE, sitting her wheelchair by her desk, looking up at him, startled. outside, banging on the door.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Open this door! She’s an old lady!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m not here to hurt you, I’ve just come to ask you a question. I’ma friend of Philomena Lee... HILDEGARDE'S eyes narrow. There is no way she is going to talk to this man. Especially not about ‘her’. He pulls a chair up to her, keeping himself at her level so as not t appear to be physically threatening.  111. MARTIN (cont'd) Why did you do it? (Beat, no response) When a mother and son were searching for each other, why did you keep them apart? HILDEGARDE looks at him, her expression that of a wily ol fox. But still she refuses to answer. Then, a door on the other side of the room - the one that opens into the corridor and which was previously locked, suddenly opens. SISTER CLAIRE - who has a master key - an the PRIEST have doubled back and now burst in. MARTIN sta up to face them.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: We're going to call the police unless you leave immediately.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m not leaving without an answer.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
