dialogues.text: I’m sorry I think your whole manner, coming in to a holy place like this, and behaving the way you have, is absolutely disgusting. He turns back to HILDEGARDE, sits down again careful not tower over her, his tone still reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Low voice, in control) I‘1l tell you what’s disgusting, lying to a dying man. (Directly to HILDEGARDE) You could have given them a few precious moments with his mother before he passed away - but you chose to lie. That’s disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Come on Sister Hildegarde, you don’t have to listen to this. Sister CLAIRE starts to wheel her away from Martin.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: Not very Christian is it- This is too much for the old nun to bear - she grabs the wheels of her wheelchair and stops her. Finally, HILDEGAR speaks, jabbing a bony finger at MARTIN.  112. SISTER HILDEGARDE (cont'd) Let me tell you something - I have kept my vow of chastity my whole life. Self denial and mortification of the flesh, that’s what brings us closer to God.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Sister Hildegarde- She wants to shut HILDEGARDE up - she clearly views her a liability. HILDEGARDE ignores her:

dialogues.speaker: SISTER HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: Those girls have nobody to blame but themselves, and their own carnal incontinence.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Sister Hildegarde - please!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You mean they had sex?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: What’s done is done - what do you expect us to do about it now?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Nothing. There’s nothing to be said. I’ve found my son, that’s what I came here for. The room falls quiet. MARTIN sees PHILOMENA standing at t door Sister Claire and the Priest came through. PHILOMENA (cont’d) (She wants to go) Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hang on hang on. He turns back to HILDEGARDE. He is starting to lose it. MARTIN (cont'd) What you can do is say sorry! How about that? Apologise. And then you can go out there and clear all the weeds and crap off the graves of the mothers and babies who died here. Stop trying to hide them away.

dialogues.speaker: HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: Their suffering was atonement for their sins.  113.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: One of them was fourteen years old!

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: (Sharply) That’s enough Martin!

dialogues.speaker: HILDEGARDE
dialogues.text: The Lord Jesus Christ will be my judge - not the likes of you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Really? Because I think if Jesus was here right now he’d tip you out of that fucking wheelchair - and you wouldn’t get up and walk.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Stop it! Stop it! (To CLAIRE and the PRIEST) I’m sorry, I didn’t want him to come in here like this and make a scene. MARTIN gets up and goes over to PHILOMENA. We see a pious smile creep across HILDEGARDE’S face.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Incredulous) Why are you apologizing to them? Anthony was dying of Aids and she still wouldn’t tell him about you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I know! But it happened to me. Not you. And it’s up to me what to do about all this. It’s my choice.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So you’re just going to do nothing?

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: No. (Beat) I’m going to forgive. (Turns to Sister Hildegarde) ) Sister Hildegarde, I want you to know that I forgive you. HILDEGARDE’S face drops and she turns her head away from PHILOMENA with an angry grunt, much happier with Martin's abuse than Philomena’s forgiveness. MARTIN looks at PHILOMENA, floored.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What..? Just like that?  114.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: It’s not ‘just like that’! It’s hard. It’s a hard thing to do. (Tears in her eyes) I don’t want to hate people. Look at you. I don’t want to be like you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Close to tears with anger and frustration) I’m angry!

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: I know. It must be exhausting. PHILOMENA smiles. She feels much better now. PHILOMENA (cont'd) Sister Claire, would you be kind enough to take me to my son’s grave. A silence. Sister CLAIRE stands.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Of course. Sister CLAIRE leads PHILOMENA out into the corridor. MART is left alone for a moment with the PRIEST and HILDEGARDE who glares at him. He turns to go, then hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well... she's outdone all of us He walks out into the corridor.

dialogues.text: He knew I’d find him here. She shuts her eyes, hands clasped together as if in silen prayer. On this we...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m not going to publish the story. She looks at him confused. MARTIN (CONT’D) It's just between you and him. She smiles, deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, I got you something. MARTIN reaches into his coat pocket and pulls out a littl plastic Jesus he has bought from the shop; the figure’s p outstretched, his heart visible through his garments. He hands it to PHILOMENA.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOMENA
dialogues.text: Oh Martin... She takes it from him and smiles, gratefully. She kneels, places the plastic Jesus on Anthony's Grave. PHILOMENA (CONT’D) Thank you. She crosses herself. As she looks at the plastic Jesus: PHILOMENA (CONT’D) You know, I'd just decided that I did want you to tell my story after all... She walks away from the grave. He follows. And now we...
